sp.p: Nay, the hole in the nose here, of some tabacco-takers, or the third nostril, (If I may so call it) which makes, that they can vent the tobacco out, like the ace of clubs, or rather the fleur-de-lis, is caused from the tobacco, the mere tobacco! when the poor innocent pox, having nothing to do there, is miserably, and most unconscionably slandered.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Who would ha' missed this, sister?

sp.speaker: Over.
sp.p: Not anybody , but Numps.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: He does not understand.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Nor you feel.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: What would you have, sister,he picketh his purse. of a fellow that knows nothing but a basket-hilt, and an old fox in't? the best music i'the fair, will not move a log.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: In, to Ursla, nightingale, and carry her comfort: see it told. This fellow was sent to us by fortune, for our first fairing.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: But what speak I of the diseases of the body, children of the fair?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: That's to us, sister. Brave i'faith!

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Hark, oh, you sons and daughters of Smithfield! and hear what malady it doth the mind: it causeth swearing, it causeth swaggering, it causeth snuffling, and snarling, and now and then a hurt.

sp.speaker: Ove.
sp.p: He hath something of master Overdo, methinks , brother.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: So methought , sister, very much of my brother Overdoo: and 'tis, when he speaks.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Look into any angle o'the town, (The straits, or the Bermuda's) where the quarrelling lesson is read, and how do they entertain the time, but with bottle-ale, and tobacco? The lecturer is o'one side, and his pupils o'the other; but the seconds are still bottle ale, and tobacco, for which the lecturer reads, and the novices pay. Thirty pound a week in boule-ale! forty in tobacco! and ten more in ale again. Then for a suit to drink in, so much, and (That being slavered) so much for another suit, and then a third suit, and a fourth suit! and still the bottle-ale slavereth, and the tobacco stinketh!

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p:
Heart of a madman! are you rooted here? well you
never away? what can any man find out in this bawling fellow, to grow here for? he is a full handful higher, sin'he heard him, will you fix here? and set up a booth? Sir?

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: I will conclude briefly ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Hold your peace, you roaring rascal, I'll run my head i'your chaps else. You were best build a booth, and entertain him, make your will, and you say the word, and him your heir! heart, I never knew one taken with a mouth of a peek, afore. By this light, I'll carry you away of my back, and you will not come. he gets him up on pickpacke.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Stay Numpes, stay, set me down: I ha' lost my purse, Numps, oh my purse! one o'my fine purses is gone.

sp.speaker: Over.
sp.p: Is't indeed, brother?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Ay, as I am an honest man, would I were an errant rogue, else! A plague of all roguy, damned cutpurses for me.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Bless 'em with all my heart, with all my heart, do you see! Now, as I am no infidel, that I know of, I am glad on't. I I am, (Here's my witness!) do you see, sir? I did not tell you of his fables, I? no, no, I am a dull malt-horse, ay, I know nothing. Are you not justly served i'your conscience now? speak i'your conscience. Much good do you with all my heart, and his good heart that has it, with all my heart again.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: This fellow is very charitable, would he had a purse too! but, I must not be too bold, all at a time.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Nay, Numps, it is not my best purse.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Not your best! death! why should it be your worst? why should it be any, indeed, at all? answer me to that, gi'me a reason from you, why it should be any?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Nor my gold, Numps; I ha' that yet, look here else, sister.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Why so, there's all the feeling he has!

sp.speaker: Over.
sp.p: I pray you, have a better care of that, brother.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Nay, so I will, I warrant you; let him catch this, that catch can. I would fain see him get this, look you here.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: So, so, so, so, so, so, so, so! Very good.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: I would ha' him come again, now, and but offer at it. Sister, will you take notice of a good jest? I will put it just where th'other was, and if we ha' good luck, you shall see a delicate fine trap to catch the cutpurse, nibbling.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Faith, and he'll try ere you be out o'the fair.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Come, mistress grace, prithee be not melancholy for my mischance; sorrow wi'not keep it, sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: I do not think on't, sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: 'Twas but a little scurvy white money, hang it: it may hang the cutpurse, one day. I ha' gold left to gi' thee a fairing, yet, as hard as the world goes: nothing angers me, but that nobody here, looked like a cutpurse, unless 'twere Numps.

sp.speaker: Was
sp.p: How? I? I look like a cutpurse? death! your sister's a cutpurse! and your mother and father, and all your kin were cutpurses! And here is a rogue is the bawd o'the cutpurses, whom I will beat to begin with.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Numps, Numps.

sp.speaker: Over.
sp.p: Good Mr. Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: You are the patrico! are you? the patriarch of the cutpurses? you share, sir, they say, let them share this with you. Are you i'your hot fit of preaching again? I'll cool you.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Murder, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Hold thy hand, child of wrath, and heir of anger,they speak all together: and Wasp beats the justice.. make it not Childermas day in thy fury, or the feast of the French Bartholmew, parent of the of the massacre.

div.head: Act. iii. Scene. i.
div.stage: Whit. Haggise. Bristle. Leatherhead. Trash.

sp.p: Nay, tish all gone, now! dish tish, phen tou vilt not be phitin call, master offisher, phat ish a man te better to lishen out noyshes for tee, and tou art in another 'orld, being very shuffishient noyshes and gallantsh too, one o'their brabblesh would have fed ush all dish fortnight, but tou art so bushy about beggersh still, tou hast no leisure to intend shentlemen, an't be.

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: Why, I told you, Davy Bristle.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p:
Come, come, you told me a pudding, Toby Haggise; a matter of nothing; I am sure it came to nothing! you said, let's go to Ursla's, indeed; but then you met the man with the monsters,
and I could not get you from him. An old fool, not leave seeing yet?

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: Why, who would ha' thought anybody would ha' quarrelled so early? or that the ale o'the fair would ha' been up so soon.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Phy? phat o'clock toest tou tinke it ish, man?

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Whi ‚ñ™
sp.p: Tou art a vishe vatchman, i'te mean teem.

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: Why? should the watch go by the clock, or the clock by the watch, I pray?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: One should go by another, if they did well.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Tou art right now! phen didst tou ever know, or hear of a shuffishient vatchman, but he did tell the clock, phat bushiness soever he had?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Nay, that's most true, a sufficient watchman knows what o'clock it is.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Shleeping, or vaking! ash well as te clock himself, or to lack dat shtrikes him!

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Let's inquire of master Leatherhead, or Joan trash here. Master Leatherhead, do you hear, master Leatherhead?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: If it be a leatherhead, tish a very tick leatherhead, tat sho much noish vill not perish him.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I have a little business now, good friends do not trouble me.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Phat? because o'ty wrought neat cap, and ty velvet sherkin, man? fie? I have sheen tee in ty ledder sherkin, ere now, mashter o'de hobby-horses, as bushy and as stately as tou sheem'st to be ‚ñ™

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Why, what an' you have, captain whit? he has his choice of jerkins, you may see by that, and his caps too, I assure you, when he pleases to be either sick, or employed.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: God a mercy Joan, answer for me.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Away, be not sheen i'my company, here be shentlemen, and men of vorship.

div.head: Act. iii. Scene. Ii.
div.stage: Qvarlous. Whit. Win-wife. Busy. John. Pvre-craft. Win. Knok. Hum. Moon-calfe. Ursla.

sp.p: We had wonderful ill luck, to miss this prologue o'the purse, but the best is, we shall have five acts of him ere night: he'll be spectacle enough! I'll answer for't.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: O Creesh! Duke quarlous, how dost tou? tou dost not know me, I fear? I am te vishesht man, but justice Overdoo, in all Bartholmew fair, now. Give me twelvepence from tee, I vill help tee to a vife vorth forty marks for't, an't be.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Away, rogue, pimp away.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: And she shall show tee as fine cut o'rke fort't in her shmock too, as tou cansht vish i'faith; vilt tou have her, vorshipfull vin vife? I vill help tee to her, here, be an't be, in te pig-quarter ‚ñ™ gi'me ty twelvepence from tee,

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: Why, there's twelvepence, pray thee wilt thou be gone.

sp.speaker: Whi,
sp.p: Tou art a vorthy man, and a vorshipfull man still.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Get you gone, rascal.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: I do mean it, man. Prinsh quarlous if tou hasht need on me, tou shalt find me here, at Ursla's, I vill see phat ale, and punk ish i'te pigsty, for tee, bless ty good vorship.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Look! who comes here! John Littlewit!

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: And his wife, and my widow, her mother: the whole family.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: 'Slight, you must give 'em all fairings, now!

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: Not I, I'll not see 'em,

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: They are going a feasting. What schoolmaster's that is with 'em?

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: That's my rival, I believe, the baker!

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: So, walk on in the middle way, foreright, turn neither to the right hand, nor to the left: let not your eyes be drawn aside with vanity, nor your ear with noises.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: O, I know him by that start!

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: What do you lack? what do you buy, pretty mistress! A fine hobby-horse, to make your son a tilter? A drum to make him a soldier? A fiddle, to make him a reveller? What is't you lack? Little dogs for your daughters! or babies, male, or female?

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Look not towards them, harken not: the place is Smithfield, or the field of smiths, the grove of hobby-horses and trinkets, the wares are the wares of devils. And the whole fair is the shop of Satan! They are hooks, and baits, very baits, that are hung out on every side, to catch you, and to hold you as it were, by the gills; and by the nostrils, as the fisher doth: therefore, you must not look, nor turn towards them ‚Äî the heathen man could stop his ears with wax, against the harlot o'the sea: do you the like, with your fingers against the bells of the beast.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: What flashes comes from him!

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: O, he has those of his oven! A notable hot baker 'twas, when he plied the peel: he is leading his flock into the fair, now.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: Rather driving 'em to the pens: for he will let 'em look upon nothing.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p:
Gentlewomen, the weather's hot! whither walk you?
Have a care o'your fine velvet caps, the fair is dusty. Take a sweet delicate booth,Littlewit is gazing at the sign; which is the pigs-head with a large writing under it. with boughs, here, i'the way, and cool yourselves i'the shade: you and your friends. The best pig and bottle-ale i' the fair, sir. Old Ursla is cook, there you may read: the pig's head speaks it. Poor soul, she has had a stringhalt, the maryhinchco: but she's prettily amended.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: A delicate sow-pig, little mistress, with sweet sauce, and crackling, like de bay-leaf I'd fire, la! Tou shalt ha'de clean side o'de tablecloth and di glass washed with phatersh of dame Annessh clear.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: This's fine, verily, here be the best pigs: and she does roast 'em as well as ever she did; the pig's head says.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Excellent, excellent, mistress, with fire of juniper and rosemary branches! The oracle of the pig's head, that, sir.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Son, were you not warned of the vanity of the eye? have you forgotten the wholesome admonition, so soon?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Good mother, how shall we find a pig, if we do not look about for't? will it run off o'the spit, into our mouths think you? as in Lubberland? and cry, we, we?

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: No, but your mother, religiously wise, conceiveth it may offer itself, by other means, to the sense, as by way of steam which I think it doth, here in this place (Huh, huh) yes, it doth. and it were a sin of obstinacy,Busy scents after it like a hound. great obstinacy, high and horrible obstinacy, to decline, or resist the good titillation of the famelick sense, which is the smell. Therefore be bold (Huh, huh, huh) follow the scent. Enter the tents of the unclean, for once, and satisfy your wife's frailty. Let your frail wife be satisfied: your zealous mother, and my suffering self, will also be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Come, win, as good whinny here, as go farther, and see nothing.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: We scape so much of the other vanities, by our early entering.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: It is an edifying consideration.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: This is scurvy, that we must come into the fair, and not look on't.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Win, have patience, win, I'll tell you more anon.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Mooncalf, entertain within there, the best pig i'the booth; a porklike pig. These are banbury-bloods, o'the sincere stud, come a pigge-hunting. Whit, wait whit, look to your charge.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: A pig prepare, presently, let a pig be prepared to us.

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.p: 'Slight, who be these?

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Is this the good service, Jordan, you'd do me?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Why, Urs? why, Urs? thou'lt ha' vapours i'thy leg again presently, pray thee go in, 't may turn to the scratches else.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Hang your vapours, they are stale, and stink like you, are these the guests o'the game, you promised to fill my pit withal, today?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: I‚óè what ail they Urs?

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Ail they? they are all sippers, sippers o'the city, they look as they would not drink off two pen'orth of bottle-ale amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Moo.
sp.p: A body may read that i'their small printed ruffs.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Away, thou art a fool, Urs, and thy mooncalf too, i'your ignorant vapours, now? hence, good guests, I say right hypocrites, good gluttons. In, and set a couple o'pigs o'the board, and half a dozen of the biggest bottles afore 'em, and call whit, I do not love to hear innocents abused: fine ambling hypocrites! and a stone-puritan, with a sorrel head, and beard, good mouthed gluttons: two to a pig, away.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Are you sure they are such?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: O'the right breed, thou shalt try 'em by the teeth, Urs, where's this whit?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Behold, man and see, what a worthy man am ee!
With the fury of my sword, and the shaking of my beard,
I will make ten thousand men afeard.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Well said, brave whit, in, and fear the ale out o'the bottles, into the bellies of the brothers, and the sister's drink to the cause, and pure vapours.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: My roarer is turned tapster, methinks . Now were a fine time for thee, Win-wife, to lay aboard thy widow, thou'lt never be master of a better season, or place; she that will venture herself into the fair, and a pig-box, will admit any assault, be assured of that.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I love not enterprises of that suddenness, though.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: I'll warrant thee, then, no wife out o'the widows hundred: if I had but as much title to her, as to have breathed once on that straight stomacher of hers, I would now assure myself to carry her, yet, ere she went out of Smithfield. Or she should carry me, which were the fitter sight, I confess. But you are a modest undertaker, by circumstances, and degrees; come, 'tis disease in thee, not judgement, I should offer at all together. Look, here's the poor fool, again, that was stung by the wasp, ere while.

div.head: Act. iii. Scene. iii.
div.stage: Justice. Win-wife. Qvarlous.

sp.p: I will make no more orations, shall draw on these tragical conclusions. And I begin now to think, that by a spice of collateral justice, Adam Overdoo, deserved this beating; for I the said Adam, was one cause (A because) why the purse was lost: and my wife's brother's purse too, which they know not of yet. But I shall make very good mirth with it, at supper, (That will be the sport) and put my little friend mr.Humphrey wasp's choler quite out of countenance. When, sitting at the upper end o'my table, as I use, and drinking to my brother Cokes, and mrs. Alice Overdoo, as I will, my wife, for their good affection to old Bradley, I deliver to 'em, it was I, that was cudgeled, and show 'em the marks. To see what bad events may peep out o'the tail of good purposes! the care I had of that civil young man, I took fancy to this morning, (And have not left it yet) drew me to that exhortation, which drew the company, indeed, which drew the cut-purse; which drew the money; which drew my brother Cokes his loss; which drew on wasp's anger; which drew on my beating: a pretty gradation! And they shall ha' it i'their dish, i'faith, at night for fruit: I love to be merry at my table. I had thought once, at one special blow he ga' me, to have revealed myself? but then (I thank thee fortitude) I remembered that a wise man (And who is ever so great a part, o'the commonwealth in himself) for no particular disaster ought to abandon a public good design. The husbandman ought not for one unthankful year, to forsake the plough; the shepherd ought not, for one scabbed sheep, to throw by his tarbox; the pilot ought not for one leak i'the poop, to quit the helm; nor the alderman ought not for one costard more, at a meal, to give up his cloak; the constable ought not to break his staff, and forswear the watch, for one roaring night; nor the piper o'the parish (Ut parvis componere magna solebam) to put up his pipes, for one rainy Sunday. These are certain knocking conclusions; out of which, I am resolved, come what come can, come beating, come imprisonment, come infamy, come banishment, nay, come the rack, come the hurdle, (Welcome all) I will not discover who I am, till my due time; and yet still, all shall be, as I said ever, in justice name, and the King's, and for the commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: What does he talk to himself, and act so seriously? poor fool!

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: No matter what. Here's fresher argument, intend that.

div.head: Act. iii. Scene. Iv.
div.stage: Cokes. Leatherhead. Waspe. Mistress Overdoo. Win-wife. Qvarlous. Trash. Grace.

sp.p: Come, mistress grace, come sister, here's more fine sights, yet i'faith. God's 'slid where's Numps?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: What do you lack, gentlemen? what is't you buy? fine rattles! Drums? Babies? little dogs? and birds for ladies? What do you lack?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Good honest Numpes, keep afore, I am so afraid thou'lt lose somewhat: my heart was at my mouth, when I missed thee.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: You were best buy a whip i'your hand to drive me.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Nay, do not mistake, Numps, thou art so apt to mistake: I would but watch the goods. Look you now, the treble fiddle, was e'en almost like to be lost.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Pray you take heed you lose not yourself: your best way, were e'en get up, and ride for more surety. Buy a token's worth of great pins, to fasten yourself to my shoulder.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: What do you lack, gentlemen? fine purses, pouches, pincases, pipes? What is't you lack? A pair o'smiths to wake you i'the morning? or a fine whistling bird?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Numps, here be finer things than any we ha' bought by odds! and more delicate horses, a great deal! good Numpes, stay ‚ñ™ and come hither.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Will you scorse with him? you are in Smithfield, you may fit yourself with a fine easy-going street-nag, for your saddle again' michaelmas-term, do, has he ne'er a little odd cart for you, to make a caroche on, i'the country, with four pied hobby-horses? why the measles, should you stand here, with your train, cheaping of dogs, birds, and babies? you ha' no children to bestow 'em on? ha' you?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: No, but again' I ha' children, Numps, that's all one.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Do, do, do, do; how many shall you have, think you? an' I were as you, I'd buy for all my tenants, too, they are a kind o' still savages, that will part with their children for rattles, pipes, and knives. You were best buy a hatchet, or two, and truck with 'em.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Good Numps, hold that little tongue o'thine, and save it a labour. I am resolute bat, thou knowest.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: A resolute fool, you are, I know, and a very sufficient coxcomb; with all my heart; nay you have it, sir, and you be angry, turd i'your teeth, twice: (If I said it not once afore) and much good do you.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Was there ever such a self-affliction? and so impertinent?

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Alas! his care will go near to crack him, let's in, and comfort him.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Would I had been set i'the ground, all but the head on me, and had my brains bowled at, or threshed out, when first I underwent this plague of a charge!

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: How now, Numps! almost tired i'your protectorship? overparted? overparted?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Why, I cannot tell, sir, it may be I am, dost grieve you?

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: No, I swear dost not, Numps: to satisfy you.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Numps? 'sblood, you are fine and familiar! how long ha' we been acquainted, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: I think it may be remembered, Numps, that? 'twas since morning sure.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Why, I hope I know't well enough, sir, I did not ask to be told.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: No? why then?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: It's no matter why, you see with your eyes, now, what I said to you today? you'll believe me another time?

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Are you removing the fair, Numps?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: A pretty question! and a very civil one! yes faith, I ha' my lading you see; or shall have anon, you may know whose beast I am, by my burden. If the pannier-man's jack were ever better known by his loins of mutton, I'll be flayed, and feed dogs for him, when his time comes.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: How melancholi mistress grace is yonder! pray thee let's go enter ourselves in grace, with her.

sp.speaker: Cok,
sp.p: Those six horses, friend I'll have ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: And the three Jews trumps; and half a dozen o'birds, and that drum, (I have one drum already) and your smiths; I like that device ‚ñ™ o'your smiths, very pretty well, and four halberts ‚Äî and (Le'me see) that fine painted great lady, and her three women for state, I'll have.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: No, the shop; buy the whole shop, it will be best, the shop, the shop!

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: If his worship please.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Yes, and keep it during the fair, bobchin.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p:
Peace, Numps, friend, do not meddle with him, an'
you be wise, and would show your head above board: he will sting thorough your wrought nightcap, believe me. A set of these violins, I would buy too, for a delicate young noise I have i'the country, that are every one a size less than another, just like your fiddles. I would fain have a fine young masque at my marriage, now I think on't: but I do want such a number o'things. And Numps will not help me now, and I dare not speak to him.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Will your worship buy any gingerbread, very good bread, comfortable bread?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Gingerbread! yes, let's see.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: There's the tother springe? he runs to her shop.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Is this well, goody Joan? to interrupt my market? in the midst? and call away my customers? can you answer this, at the piepowders?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Why? if his mastership have a mind to buy, I hope my ware lies as open as another's; I may show my ware, as well as you yours.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Hold your peace; I'll content you both: I'll buy up his shop, and thy basket.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Will you i'faith?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Why should you put him from it, friend?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Cry you mercy! you'd be sold too, would you? what's the price on you? Jerkin, and all as you stand? ha' you any qualities?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes, goodman angry-man, you shall find he has qualities, if you cheapen him.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: God's so, you ha' the selling of him! what are they? will they be bought for love, or money?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: No indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: For what then? victuals?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: He scorns victuals, sir, he has bread and butter at home, thanks be to God! and yet he will do more for a good meal, if the toy take him i'the belly, marry than they must not set him at lower end; if they do, he'll go away, though he fast. But put him a top o'the table, where his place is, and he'll do you forty five things. He has not been sent for, and sought out for nothing, at your great city-suppers, to put down Coriat, and Cokeley, and been laughed at for his labour; he'll play you all the puppets i'the town over, and the players, every company, and his own company too; he spares nobody !

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: I'faith?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: He was the first, sir, that ever baited the fellow i'the bear's skin, an't like your worship: no dog ever came near him, since. And for fine motions!

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Is he good at those too? can he set out a masque trow?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p:
O lord, master! sought to far, and near, for his inventions:
and he engrosses all, he makes all the puppets i'the fair.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Dost thou (In troth) old velvet jerkin ‚ñ™ give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Nay, sir, you shall see him in his velvet jerkin, and a scarf, too, at night, when you hear him interpret master Littlewit's motion.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Speak no more, but shut up shop presently, friend. I'll buy both it, and thee too, to carry down with me, and her hamper, beside. Thy shop shall furnish out the masque, and hers the banquet: I cannot go less, to set out any thing with credit ‚ñ™ what's the price, at a word, o'thy whole shop, case, and all as it stands?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Sir, it stands me in six and twenty shillings seven pence, halfpenny, besides three shillings for my ground.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Well, thirty shillings will do all, then! And what comes yours too?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Four shillings, and eleven pence, sir, ground, and all, an't like your worship.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Yes, it does like my worship very well, poor woman, that's five shillings more, what a masque shall I furnish out, for forty shillings? (Twenty pound Scotch) and a banquet of gingerbread? there's a stately thing! Numps? Sister? and my wedding gloves too? (That I never thought on afore.) All my wedding gloves, gingerbread? O me! what a device will there be? to make 'em eat their fingers ends! and delicate brooches for the bridemen! and all! and then I'll ha' this poesy put to 'em: for the best grace, meaning mistress grace, my wedding poesy.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: I am beholden to you, sir, and to your bartholmew-wit.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: You do not mean this, do you? is this your first purchase?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Yes faith, and I do not think, Numpes, but thou'lt say, it was the wisest act, that ever I did in my wardship.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Like enough! I shall say any thing. I!

div.head: Act. iii. Scene. V.
div.stage: Justice. Edgvvorth. Nightingale.

sp.p: I cannot beget a project, with all my political brain, yet; my project is how to fetch off this proper young man, from his debauched company: I have followed him all the fair over, and still I find him with this songster: and I begin shrewdly to suspect their familiarity; and the young man of a terrible taint, poetry! with which idle disease, if he be infected, there's no hope of him, in a state-course. Actum est, of him for a commonwealths-man: if he go to't in rhyme, once.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Yonder he is buying o'ginger-bread: set in quickly, before he part with too much on his money.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: My masters and friends, and good people, draw near, etc.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Ballads! hark, hark! pray thee, fellow, stay a little,he runs to the ballad man. good Numpes, look to the goods. What ballads hast thou? let me see, let me see myself.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Why so! he's flown 'to another limebush, there he will flutter as long more; till he ha' ne'er a feather left. Is there a vexation like this, gentlemen? will you believe me now, hereafter? shall I have credit with you?

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Yes faith, shalt thou, Numps, and thou art worthy on't, for thou sweatest for't. I never saw a young pimp errant, and his squire better matched.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: Faith, the sister comes after 'em, well, too.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Nay, if you saw the justice her husband, my guardian, you were fitted for the mess, he is such a wise one his way ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: I wonder, we see him not here.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: O! he is too serious for this place, and yet better sport than then the other three, I assure you, gentlemen: where ere he is, though't be o'the bench.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: How dost thou call it! A caveat against cutpurses! A good jest, i'faith, I would fain see that daemon, your cutpurse, you talk of, that delicate handed devil;he shows his purse boastingly. they say he walks hereabout; I would see him walk, now. Look you sister, here, here, let him come, sister, and welcome. Ballad-man, does any cutpurses haunt hereabout? pray thee raise me one or two ‚ñ™ begin and show me one.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p:
Sir, this is a spell against 'em, spick and span new; and 'tis made as 'twere in mine own person, and I sing it in mine own
defence. But 'twill cost a penny alone, if you buy it.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: No matter for the price, thou dost not know me, I see, I am an odd Bartholmew.

sp.speaker: Ove.
sp.p: Hast a fine picture, brother?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: O sister, do you remember the ballads over the nursery-chimney at home of my own pasting up, there be brave pictures. Other manner of pictures, than these, friend.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Yet these will serve to pick the pictures out of your pockets, you shall see.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: So, I heard 'em say. Pray thee mind him not, fellow: he'll have an oar in every thing.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: It was intended sir, as if a purse should chance to be cut in my presence, now, I may be blameless, though: as by the sequel, will more plainly appear.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: We shall find that i'the matter. Pray thee begin.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: To the tune of Paggington's pound, sir.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Fa, la la la, la la la, fa la la la. Nay, I'll put thee in tune, and all! mine own country dance! Pray thee begin.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: It is a gentle admonition, you must know, sir, both to the purse-cutter, and the purse-bearer.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Not a word more, out o'the tune, an' thou lovest me: fa, la la la, la la la, fa la la la. Come, when?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: My masters and friends, and good people draw near,
And look to your purses, for that I do say;

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Ha, ha, this chimes! good counsel at first dash.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: And though little money, in them you do bear.
It cost more to get, than to lose in a day. Cok. good!
You oft have been told,
Both the young and the old;Cok. well said! he were to blame that would not i'faith.
And bidden beware of the cutpurse so bold:
Then if you take heed not, free me from the curse,
Who both give you warning, for and, the cutpurse.
Youth, youth, thou hadst better been starved by thy nurse,
Then live to be hanged for cutting a purse.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Good i'faith, how say you, Numps? Is there any harm i'this?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: It hath been upbraided to men of my trade,Cok. the more coxcombs they that did it, I wiss.
That often times we are the cause of this crime.
Alack and for pity, why should it be said?
As if they regarded or places, or time.
Examples have been
Of some that were seen,
In Westminster hall, yea the pleaders between,Cok. God a mercy for that! why should they be more free indeed?
Then why should the judges be free from this curse,
More than my poor self, for cutting the purse?
Youth, youth, thou hadst better been starved by the nurse,
Then live to be hanged for cutting a purse.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: That again, good ballad-man, that again. O rare! he sings the burden with him. I would fain rub mine elbow now, but I dare not pull out my hand. On, I pray thee, he that made this ballad, shall be poet to my masque.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: At Worc'ter 'tis known well, and even i'the ‚óèayle,
A knight of good worship did there show his face,
Against the foul sinners, in zeal for to rail,
And lost (Ipso facto) his purse in the place. Cok. is it possible?
Nay, once from the seat
Of judgement so great,
A judge there did lose a fair pouch of velvet. Cok. i'faith?
O lord for thy mercy, how wicked or worse,
Are those that so venture their necks for a purse! Youth, youth, etc.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Youth, youth, and c? pray thee stay a little, friend, yet o'thy conscience, Numps, speak, is there any harm i'this?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: To tell you true, 'tis too good for you, less you had grace to follow it.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: It doth discover enormity, I'll mark it more: I ha' not liked a paltry piece of poetry, so well a good while.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Youth, youth, and c! where's this youth, now? A man must call upon him, for his own good, and yet he will not appear: look here, here's for him, handy-dandy,he shows his purse. which hand will he have? On, I pray there, with the rest, I do hear of him, but I cannot see him, this master youth, the cutpurse.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: At plays and at sermons, and at the sessions,
'Tis daily their practice such booty to make:
Yea, under the gallows, at executions,
They stick not the stare-abouts purses to take.
Nay one without-grace,Cok. that was a fine fellow! I would have him, now.
At a better place,
At court, and in Christmas, before the King's face,
Alack then for pity must I bear the curse,
That only belongs to the cunning cutpurse?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: But where's their cunning, now, when they should use it? they are all chained now, I warrant you. Youth, youth, thou hadst better, etc. The rat-catcher charm, are all fools and asses to this! A pox on 'em, that they will not come! that a man should have such a desire to a thing, and want it.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Before God, I'd give half the fair, and 'twere mine, for a cutpurse for him, to save his longing.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Look you sister, here, here, where is't now?he shows his purse again. which pocket is't in? for a wager?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: I beseech you leave your wagers, and let him end his matter, an't may be.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: O, are you edified Numps?

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Indeed he does interrupt him, too much: there Numps spoke to purpose.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: again. sister, I am an ass, I cannot keep my purse: on, on; I pray thee, friend.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.l: But oh, you vile nation of cutpurses all,
Relent and repent, and amend and be sound,
Edgworth gets up to him, and tickles him in the care with a straw twice to draw his hand out of his pocket. and know that you ought not, by honest men's fall,
Advance your own fortunes, to die above ground,
And though you go gay,
In silks as you may,
It is not the high way to heaven, (As they say)
Repent then, repent you, for better, for worse:
And kiss not the gallows for cutting a purse.
Youth, youth, thou hadst better been starved by thy nurse,
Then live to be hanged for cutting a purse.

sp.speaker: Winw.
sp.p: Will you see sport? look, there's a fellow gathers up to him, mark.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Good, i' faith! O he has lighted on the wrong pocket. Winw. He has it, 'fore God he is a brave fellow; pity he should be detected.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: An excellent ballad! an excellent ballad!

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Friend, let me ha' the first, let me ha' the first, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Pardon me, sir. First come, first served; and I'll buy the whole bundle too.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: That conveyance was better than all, did you see't? he has given the purse to the ballad-singer.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Has he?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Sir, I cry you mercy; I'll not hinder the poor man's profit: pray you mistake me not.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Sir, I take you for an honest gentleman; if that be mistaking, I met you today afore: ha! humh! O God! my purse is gone, my purse, my purse, etc.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Come, do not make a stir, and cry yourself an ass, thorough the fair afore your time.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Why, hast thou it, Numpes? good Numpes, how came you by it? I mar'le!

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: I pray you seek some other gamester, to play the fool with: you may lose it time enough, for all your fair-wit.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: By this good hand, glove and all, I ha' lost it already, if thou hast it not: feel else, and mistress grace's handkercher, too, out o'the tother pocket.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Why, 'tis well; very well, exceeding pretty, and well.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Are you sure you ha' lost it, sir?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: O God! yes; as I am an honest man, I had it but e'en now, at youth, youth.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: I hope you suspect not me, sir.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Thee? that were a jest indeed! Dost thou think the gentleman is foolish? where hadst thou hands, I pray thee? Away ass, away.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: I shall be beaten again, if I be spied.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Sir, I suspect an odd fellow, yonder, is stealing away.

sp.speaker: Ove.
sp.p: Brother, it is the preaching fellow! you shall suspect him. He was at your tother purse, you know! Nay, stay, sir, and view the work you ha'done, an you be beneficed at the gallows, and preach there, thank your own handiwork.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Sir, you shall take no pride in your preferment: you shall be silenced quickly.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: What do you mean? sweet buds of gentility.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: To ha' my pennyworths out on you: bud. No less than two purses a day, serve you? I thought you a simple fellow, when my man Numpes beat you, i'the morning, and pitied you ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Ove.
sp.p: So did I, I'll be sworn, brother; but now I see he is a lewd, and pernicious enormity: (As master Overdoo calls him.)

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Mine own words turned upon me, like swords.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Cannot a man's purse be at quiet for you, i'the master's pocket, but you must entice it forth, and debauch it?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Sir, sir, keep your debauch, and your fine bartholmew-termes to yourself; and make as much on 'em as you please. But gi'me this from you, i'the mean time: I beseech you, see if I can look to this. wasp takes the licence from him.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Why, Numps?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Why? because you are an ass, sir, there's a reason the shortest way, and you will needs ha' it; now you ha'got the trick of losing, you'd lose your breech, an't 'twere loose. I know you, sir, come, deliver, you'll go and crack the vermin, you breed now, will you? 'tis very fine, will you ha' the truth on't? they are such reckless flies as you are, that blow cutpurses abroad in every corner; your foolish having of money, makes 'em. An' there were no wiser than I, sir, the trade should lie open for you, sir, it should i'faith, sir. I would teach your wit to come to your head, sir, as well as your land to come into your hand, I assure you, sir.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Alack, good Numps.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Nay, gentlemen, never pity me, I am not worth it: lord send me at home once, to harrow o'the hill again, if I travel any more, call me Coriat; withal my heart.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Stay, sir, I must have a word with you in private. Do you hear?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: With me, sir? what's your pleasure? good sir.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Do not deny it. You are a cutpurse, sir, this gentleman here, and I, saw you, nor do we mean to detect you (Though we can sufficiently inform ourselves, towards the danger of concealing you) but you must do us a piece of service.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Good gentlemen, do not undo me; I am a civil young man, and but a beginner, indeed.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p:
Sir, your beginning shall bring on your ending, for us.
we are no catchpoles nor constables. That you are to undertake, is this; you saw the old fellow, with the black box, here?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: The little old governor, sir?

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: That same: I see, you have flown him to a mark already. I would ha'you get away that box from him, and bring it us.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Would you ha' the box and all, sir? or only that, that is in't? I'll get you that, and leave him the box, to play with still: (Which will be the harder o'the two) because I would gain your worship's good opinion of me.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: He says well, 'tis the greater mastery, and 'twill make the more sport when 'tis missed.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Ay, and 'twill be the longer a missing, to draw on the sport.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: But look you do it now, sirrah, and keep your word: or ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Sir, if ever I break my word, with a gentleman, may I never read word at my need. Where shall I find you?

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Somewhere i'the fair, hereabouts. Dispatch it quickly. I would fain see the careful fool deluded! of all beasts, I love the serious ass. He that takes pains to be one, and plays the fool, with the greatest diligence that can be.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Then you would not choose, sir, but love my guardian, justice Overdo, who is answerable to that description, in every hair of him.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: So I have heard. But how came you, mistress Welborne, to be his ward? or have relation to him, at first?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Faith, through a common calamity, he bought me, sir; and now he will marry me to his wife's brother, this wise gentleman, that you see, or else I must pay value o'my land

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: 'Slid, is there no device of disparagement? or so? talk with some crafty fellow, some picklock o'the law! Would I had studied a year longer i'the inns of court, an't had been but i'your case.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: I master quarlous, are you proffering?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: You'd bring but little aid, sir.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: (I'll look to you i'faith, gamester.) An unfortunate foolish tribe you are fallen into, lady, I wonder you can endure 'em.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Sir, they that cannot work their fetters off; must wear 'em.

sp.speaker: Winw.
sp.p: You see what care they have on you, to leave you thus.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Faith the same they have of themselves, sir. I cannot greatly complain, if this were all the plea I had against 'em.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p:
'Tis true! but will you please to withdraw with us, a little, and make them think, they have lost you. I hope our manners ha' been such hitherto, and our language, as will give
you no cause, to doubt yourself, in our company.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Sir, I will give myself, no cause; I am so secure of mine own manners, as I suspect not yours.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Look where John Littlewit comes.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: Away, I'll not be seen, by him.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: No, you were not best, he'd tell his mother, the widow.

sp.speaker: Win W.
sp.p: Heat, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Cry you mercy, is the wind there? must not the widow be named?

div.head: Act. iii scene. Vi.
div.stage: John. Win. trash. Leatherhead. Knockhum. Busy. pure craft.

sp.p: Do you hear win, win?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: What say you, John?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: While they are paying the reckoning, win, I'll tell you a thing win, we shall never see any sights i'the fair, win, except you long still, win, good Win, sweet Win, long to see some hobby-horses, and some drums, and rattles, and dogs, and fine devices, win. The bull with the five legs, win; and the great hog: now you ha' begun with pig, you may long for any thing, win, and so for my motion, win.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: But we sha'not eat o'the bull, and the hog, John, how shall I long then?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: O yes! Win: you may long to see, as well as to taste, win: how did the pothecary's wife, win, that longed to see the anatomy, win? or the lady, win, that desired to spit i'the great lawyer's mouth, after an eloquent pleading? I assure you they longed, win, good Win, go in, and long.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I think we are rid of our new customer, brother Leatherhead, we shall hear no more of him. they plot to be gone.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: All the better, let's pack up all, and be gone, before he find us

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Stay a little, yonder comes a company: it may be we may take some more money.

sp.speaker: Kno,
sp.p: Sir, I will take your counsel, and cut my hair, and leave vapours: I see, that tobacco, and bottle-ale, and big, and whit, and very Ursla, herself, is all vanity.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p:
Only pig was not comprehended in my admonition,
the rest were. For long hair, it is an ensign of pride, a banner, and the world is full of those banners, very full of banners. And, bottle-ale is a drink of Sathan's, a diet-drink of Satan's, devised to puff us up, and make us swell in this latter age of vanity, as the smoke of tobacco, to keep us in mist and error: but the fleshly woman, (Which you call Ursla) is above all to be avoided, having the marks upon her, of the three enemies of man, the world, as being in the fair; the devil, as being in the fire; and and the flesh, as being herself.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Brother Zeal-of-the-land ! what shall we do? my daughter Win-the-fight, is fallen into her fit of longing again.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: For more pig? there is no more, is there?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: To see some sights, i' the fair.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Sister, let her fly the impurity of the place, swiftly, lest she partake of the pitch thereof. Thou art the seat of the beast, oh Smithfield, and I will leave thee. Idolatry peepeth out on every side of thee.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: An excellent right hypocrite! now his belly is full, he falls a railing and kicking, the jade. A very good vapour! I'll in, and joy Ursla, with telling, how her pig works, two and a half he eat to his share. And he has drunk a pailful. He eats with his eyes, as well as his teeth.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: What do you lack, gentlemen? What is't you buy? Rattles, drums, babies. ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Peace, with thy apocryphal wares, thou profane publican: thy bells, thy dragons, and thy Tobie's dogs. Thy hobby-horse is an idol, a very idol, a fierce and rank idol: and thou, the Nabuchadnezzar, the proud Nabuchadnezzar of the fair, that settest it up, for children to fall down to, and worship.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Cry you mercy, sir, will you buy a fiddle to fill up your noise.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Look win. do, look a god's name, and save your longing. Here be fine sights.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: I child, so you hate 'em, as our brother zeal does, you may look on 'em.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Or what do you say, to a drum. Sir?

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: It is the broken belly of the beast, and thy bellows there are his lungs, and these pipes are his throat, those feathers are of his tail, and thy rattles, the gnashing of his teeth.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: And what's my gingerbread? I pray you.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: The provender that pricks him up. Hence with thy basket of popery, thy nest of images: and whole legend of ginger-work.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Sir if you be not quiet, the quicklier, I'll ha'you clapped fairly by the heels, for disturbing the fair.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: The sin of the fair provokes me, I cannot be silent.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Good brother zeal!

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Sir, I'll make you silent, believe it.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: I'd give a shilling, you could i'faith, friend.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Sir, give me your shilling, I'll give you my shop, if I do not, and I'll leave it in pawn with you, i'the mean time.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: A match i'faith, but do it quickly, then.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Hinder me not, woman. I was moved in spirit,he speaks to the widow. to be here, this day, in this fair, this wicked, and foul fair; and fitter may it be a called a foul, than a fair: to protest against the abuses of it, the foul abuses of it, in regard of the afflicted saints, that are troubled, very much troubled, exceedingly troubled, with the opening of the merchandise of Babylon again, and the peeping of popery upon the stalls, here, here, in the high places. See you not Goldilocks, the purple strumpet, there? in her yellow gown, and green sleeves? the profane pipes, the tinkling timbrels? A shop of relics!

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Pray you forbear, I am put in trust with 'em.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: And this idolatrous grove of images, this flasket of idols!overthrows the gingerbread. which I will pull down ‚Äî
(Tra. O my ware, my ware, God bless it.)

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: In my zeal, and glory to be thus exercised.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Here he is, pray you lay hold on his zeal, we cannot sell a whistle, for him, in tune. Stop his noise, first!

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Thou canst not: 'tis a sanctified noise. Leatherhead enters with officersI will make a loud and most strong noise, till I have daunted the profane enemy. And for this cause. ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Sir, here's no man afraid of you, or your cause. You shall swear it, i'the stocks, sir.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: I will thrust myself into the stocks, upon the pikes of the land.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Carry him away.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: What do you mean, wicked men?

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Let them alone; I fear them not.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Was not this shilling well ventured, win? for our liberty? Now we may go play, and see over the fair, where we list ourselves; my mother is gone after him, and let her e'en go, and lose us.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Yes John, but I know not what to do.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: For what, win?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: For a thing, I am ashamed to tell you, i'faith, and 'tis too far to go home.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: I pray thee be not ashamed, win. Come, i'faith thou shall not be ashamed, is it any thing about the hobby-horse-man? an't be, speak freely.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Hang him, base bobchin, I scorn him; no, I have very great, what shall call 'em, John.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p:
O! Is that all, win? we'll go back to captain Jordan; to the pig-woman's, win. he'll help us, or she with a
dripping pan, or an old kettle, or something. The poor greasy soul loves you, win, and after we'll visit the fair all over, win, and, see my puppet play, win, you know it's a fine matter, win.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Let's away, I counselled you to pack up afore, Joan.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: A pox of his bedlam purity. He has spoiled half my ware: but the best is, we lose nothing, if we miss our first merchant.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: It shall be hard for him to find, or know us, when we are translated, Joan.

div.head: Act. iv. Scene. i.
div.stage: Trovble-all. Bristle. Haggise, Cokes. Justice. Pocher, Busy. Purecraft.

sp.p: My masters, I do make no doubt, but you are officers.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: What then, sir?

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: And the Kings loving, and obedient subjects.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Obedient, friend? take heed what you speak, I advise you: Oliver Bristle advises you. His loving subjects, we grant you: but not his obedient, at this time, by your leave, we know ourselves, a little better than so, we are to command, sir and such as you are to be obedient. Here's one of his obedient subjects, going to the stocks, and we'll make you such another, if you talk.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: You are all wise enough i'your places, I know.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: If you know it, sir, why do you bring it in question?

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: I question nothing, pardon me. I do only hope you have warrant, for what you do, and so, quit you, and so, multiply you.

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: he goes away again. what's he? bring him up to the stocks there. Why bring you him not up?

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: If you have justice Ouerdoo's warrant, 'tis well:comes again. you are safe; that is the warrant of warrants. I'll not give this button, for any man's warrant else.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Like enough, sir, but let me tell you, an' you play away your buttons, thus, you will want 'em ere night,goes away. for any store I see about you: you might keep 'em, and save pins, I wiss.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: What should he be, that doth so esteem, and advance my warrant? he seems a sober and discreet person! it is a comfort to a good conscience, to be followed with a good fame, in his sufferings. The world will have a pretty taste by this, how I can bear adversity: and it will beget a kind of reverence, towards me, hereafter, even from mine enemies, when they shall see I carry my calamity nobly, and that it doth neither break me, nor bend me.

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: Come, sir, here's a place for you to preach in. they put him in the stocks. will you put in your leg?

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: That I will, cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: O'my conscience a seminary! he kisses the stocks.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Well my masters, I'll leave him with you; now I see him bestowed, I'll go look for my goods, and Numps.

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: You may, sir, I warrant you; where's the tother bawler? fetch him too, you shall find 'em both fast enough.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: In the midst of this tumult, I will yet be the author of mine own rest, and not minding their fury, sit in the stocks, in that calm, as shall be able to trouble a triumph.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Do you assure me upon your words?comes again, may I undertake for you, if I be asked the question; that you have this warrant?

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: What's this fellow, for god's sake?

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Do but show me Adam Overdoo, and I am satisfied ‚ñ™goes out.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: He is a fellow that is distracted, they say; one Trouble-all ‚ñ™ he was an officer in the court of pie-poulders, here last year, and put out on his place by justice Overdoo.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Upon which, he took an idle conceit, and's run mad upon't. So that ever since, he will do nothing, but by justice Ouerdoo's warrant, he will not eat a crust, nor drink a little, nor make him in his apparel, ready. His wife, sirreverence, cannot get him make his water, or shift his shirt, without his warrant.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: If this be true, this is my greatest disaster! how am I bound to satisfy this poor man, that is of so good a nature to me, out of his wits! where there is no room left for dissembling. comes in.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: If you cannot show me Adam Overdoo, I am in doubt of you: I am afraid you cannot answer it.

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: Before me,goes again. neighbour Bristle (And now I think on't better) justice Overdoo, is a very parantory person.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: O! are you advised of that? and a severe justicer, by your leave.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Do I hear ill o'that side, too?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: He will sit as upright o'the bench, an' you mark him, as a candle i'the socket, and give light to the whole court in every business.

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: But he will burn blue, and swell like a boil (God bless us) an' he be angry.

sp.speaker: Bri ..
sp.p: Ay, and he will be angry too, when his list, that's more: and when he is angry, be it right or wrong; he has the law on's side, ever. I mark that too.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: I will be more tender hereafter. I see compassion may become a justice, though it be a weakness, I confess; and nearer a vice, than a virtue.

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: they take the justice out. well, take him out of the stocks again, we'll go a sure way to work, we'll ha' the ace of hearts of our side, if we can.

sp.speaker: Poc.
sp.p: Come, bring him away to his fellow, there. Master busy, we shall rule your legs, I hope, though we cannot rule your tongue.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: No, minister of darkness, no, thou canst not rule my tongue, my tongue it is mine own; and with it I will both knock and mock down your Bartholmew abominations, till you „Äà‚óä„Äâ made a hissing to the neighbour parishes, round about.

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: Let him alone, we have devised better upon't.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: And shall he not into the stocks then?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: No, mistress, we'll have 'em both to justice Overdoo, and let him do over 'em as is fitting. Then I, and my gossip Haggis, and my beadle poacher are discharged.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O, I thank you, blessed, honest men!

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Nay, never thank us, but thank this madman that comes here, he put it in our heads.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Is he mad? Now heaven increase his madness, and bless it,comes again. and thank it, sir, your poor handmaid thanks you.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Have you a warrant? an' you have a warrant, show it.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Yes, I have a warrant out of the word, to give thanks for removing any scorn intended to the brothers.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: It is justice Ouerdoo's warrant, that I look for, if you have not that, keep your word, I'll keep mine. Quit ye, and multiply ye.

div.head: Act. iv. Scene. Ii.
div.stage: Edgvvorth. Trovble-all. Nightingale. Cokes. Costard-monger.

sp.p: Come away nightingale, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Whither go you? where's your warrant?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Warrant, for what, sir?

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: For what you go about, you know how fit it is, an' you have no warrant, bless you, I'll pray for you,goes out. that's all I can do.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: What means he?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: A madman that haunts the fair, do you not know him? it's marvel he has not more followers, after his ragged heels.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Beshrew him, he startled me: I thought he had known of our plot. Guilt's a terrible thing! ha' you prepared the costard-monger?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Yes, and agreed for his basket of pears; he is at the corner here, ready. And your prize, he comes down, sailing, that way, all alone; without his protector: he is rid of him, it seems.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Ay, I know; I should ha' followed his protectorship for a feat I am to do upon him: but this offered itself, so i'the way, I could not let it scape: here he comes, whistle,Nightingale whistles be this sport called dorring the dotterel.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Wh, wh, wh, wh, etc.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: By this light, I cannot find my gingerbread-wife, nor my hobby-horse-man in all the fair, now; to ha' my money again. And I do not know the way out on't, to go home for more, do you hear, friend, you that whistle; what tune is that, you whistle?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: A new tune, I am practising, sir.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Dost thou know where I dwell, I pray thee? nay, on with thy tune, I ha' no such haste, for an answer: I'll practise with thee. Nightingale sets his foot afore him, and he falls with his basket.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.p: Buy any pears, very fine pears, pears fine.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: God's so! A musse, a musse, a musse, a musse.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.p: Good gentleman, my ware, my ware, I am a poor man. Good sir, my ware.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Cokes falls a scrambling whilst they run away with his things. let me hold your sword, sir, it troubles you.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Do, and my cloak, an'thou wilt; and my hat, too.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: A delicate great boy! methinks , he out-scrambles 'em all. I cannot persuade myself, but he goes to grammar-school yet; and plays the truant, today.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Would he had another purse to cut, Zekiel.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Purse? A man might cut out his kidneys, I think; and he never feel 'em, he is so earnest at the sport.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: His soul is half way out on's body, at the game.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Away, nightingale: that way.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: I think I am furnished for Catherne pears, for one undermeal: gi'me my cloak.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.p: Good gentleman, give me my ware.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Where's the fellow, I give my cloak to? my cloak? and my hat?he runs out. ha! Gods'lid, is he gone? thieves, thieves, help me to cry, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Away, costermonger, come to us to Ursla's. Talk of him to have a soul? 'heart, if he have any more than a thing given him in stead of salt, only to keep him from stinking, I'll be hanged afore my time, presently, where should it be trow? in his blood; he has not so much toward it in his whole body, as will maintain a good flea; and if he take this course, he will not ha' so much land left, as to rear a calf within this twelvemonth . Was there ever green plover so pulled! That his little overseer had been here now, and been but tall enough, to see him steal pears, in exchange, for his beaver-hat, and his cloak thus? I must go find him out, next, for his black box, and his patent (It seems) he has of his place; which I think the gentleman would have a reversion of; that spoke to me for it so earnestly.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: he comes again. would I might lose my doublet, and hose, too; as I am an honest man, and never stir, if I think there be any thing, but thieving, and cozening, i'this whole fair ‚ñ™ Bartholmew-fair, quoth he; an' ever any Bartholmew had that luck in't, that I have had, I'll be martyred for him,throws away his pears. and in Smithfield, too. I ha' paid for my pears, a rot on 'em, I'll keep 'em no longer; you were choake-peares to me; I had been better ha'gone to mum chance for you, I wiss. Methinks the fair should not have used me thus, and 'twere but for my name's sake, I would not ha' used a dog o'the name, so. O, Numps will triumph, now! Friend, do you know who I am? or where I lie? I do not myself, I'll be sworn. Do but carry me home, and I'll please thee, I ha' money enough there, I ha' lost myself, and my cloak and my hat; and my fine sword, and my sister, and Numps, and mistress grace, (A gentlewoman that I should ha' married) and a cutwork handkercher, she give me, and two purses today. And my bargain o'hobby-horses and gingerbread, which grieves me worst of all.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Trouble-all comes again. by whose warrant, sir, have you done all this?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Warrant? thou art a wise fellow, indeed, as if a man need a warrant to lose any thing, with.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Yes, justice Ouerdo's warrant, a man may get, and lose with, I'll stand to't.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Justice Overdoo? Dost thou know him? I lie there, he is my brother in law, he married my sister: pray thee show me the way, dost thou know the house?

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Sir, show me your warrant, I know nothing without a warrant, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Why, I warrant thee, come along: thou shalt see, I have wrought pillows there, and cambric sheets, and sweet bags, too. Pray thee guide me to the house.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Sir, I'll tell you; go you thither yourself, first, alone; tell your worshipful brother your mind: and but bring me three lines of his hand, or his clerks, with Adam Overdoo, underneath; here I'll stay you, I'll obey you, and I'll guide you presently.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: 'Slid, this is an ass, I ha' found him, pox upon me, what do I talking to such a dull fool; farewell, you are a very coxcomb, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: I think, I am, if justice Overdoo sign to it, I am, and so we are all, he'll quit us all, multiply us all.

div.head: Act. iiii.
Scene. Iv.
div.stage: Grace. Qvarlous. Win-wife. they enter with their swords drawn. Trovble-all. Edgvvorth.
div.p: Gentlemen, this is no way that you take: you do but breed one another trouble, and offence, and give me no contentment at all. I am no she, that affects to be quarrelled for, or have my name or fortune made the question of men's swords.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: 'Sblood, we love you.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: If you both love me, as you pretend, your own reason will tell you, but one can enjoy me; and to that point, there leads a directer line, then by my infamy, which must follow, if you fight. 'tis true, I have professed it to you ingenuously, that rather than to be yoked with this bridegroom is appointed me, I would take up any husband, almost upon any trust. Though subtlety would say to me, (I know) he is a fool, and has an estate, and I might govern him, and enjoy a friend, beside. But these are not my aims, I must have a husband I must love, or I cannot live with him. I shall ill make one of these politic wives!

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: Why, if you can like either of us, lady, say, which is he, and the other shall swear instantly to desist.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Content, I accord to that willingly.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Sure you think me a woman of an extreme levity, gentlemen, or a strange fancy, that (Meeting you by chance in such a place, as this, both at one instant, and not yet of two hours acquaintance, neither of you deserving afore the other, of me) I should so forsake my modesty (Though I might affect one more particularly) as to say, this is he, and name him.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Why, wherefore should you not? What should hinder you?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: If you would not give it to my modesty, allow it yet to my wit; give me so much of woman, and cunning, as not to betray myself impertinently. How can I judge of you, so far as to a choice, without knowing you more? you are both equal, and alike to me, yet: and so indifferently affected by me, as each of you might be the man, if the other were away. For you are reasonable creatures, you have understanding, and discourse. And if fate send me an understanding husband, I have no fear at all, but mine own manners shall make him a good one.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Would I were put forth to making for you, then.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: It may be you are, you know not what's towards you: will you consent to a motion of mine, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Winw.
sp.p: whatever it be, we'll presume reasonableness, coming from you.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: And fitness, too.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: I saw one of you buy a pair of tables, e'en now.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: Yes, here they be, and maiden ones too, unwritten in.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: The fitter for what they may be employed in. You shall write either of you, here, a word, or a name, what you like best; but of two, or three syllables at most: and the next person that comes this way (Because destiny has a high hand in business of this nature) I'll demand, which of the two words, he, or she doth approve; and according to that sentence, fix my resolution, and affection, without change.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Agreed, my word is conceived already.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: And mine shall not be long creating after.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: But you shall promise, gentlemen, not to be curious to know, which of you it is, taken; but give me leave to conceal that till you have brought me, either home, or where I may safely tender myself.

sp.speaker: Win-w
sp.p: Why that's but equal.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: We are pleased.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Because I will bind both your endeavours to work together, friendly, and jointly, each to the others fortune, and have myself fitted with some means, to make him that is forsaken, a part of amends.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: These conditions are very courteous. Well my word is out of the Arcadia, then: Argalus.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: And mine out of the play, Palemon.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Have you any warrant for this, gentlemen? Trouble-all comes again.

sp.speaker: Qvar. Win-w.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: There must be a warrant had, believe it.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: For whatsoever it is, any thing indeed, no matter what.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: 'Slight, here's a fine ragged prophet, dropped down i'the nick!

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Heaven quit you, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Nay, stay a little, good lady, put him to the question.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: You are content, then?

sp.speaker: Win-w. Qvar.
sp.p: Yes yes.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Sir, here are two names written ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Is judice Overdoo, one?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: How, sir? I pray you read 'em to yourself, it is for a wager between these gentlemen, and with a stroke or any difference, mark which you approve best.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: They may be both worshipful names for ought I know, mistress, but Adam Overdoo had been worth three of 'em, I assure you, in this place, that's in plain English.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: This man amazes me! I pray you, like one of 'em, sir.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: I do like him there, that has the best warrant, mistress, to save your longing, and (Multiply him) it may be this. But I am I still for justice Overdoo, that's my conscience. And quit you.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: Is't done, lady?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Ay, and strangely, as ever I saw! What fellow is this trow?

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: No matter what, a fortune-teller we ha' made him. Which is't, which is't.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Nay, did you not promise, not to inquire?

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: 'Slid, I forgotten that, pray you pardon me. Look, here's our Mercury come: the licence arrives i'the finest time, too! 'tis but scraping out cokes his name, and 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: How now lime-twig? hast thou touched.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Not yet, sir, except you would go with me, and see't, it's not worth speaking on. The act is nothing, without a witness. Yonder he is, your man with the box fallen into the finest company, and so transported with vapours, they ha' got in a Northern clothier, and one puppy, a western man, that's come to wrestle before my lord mayor, anon, and captain whit, and one Val cutting, that helps captain Jordan to roar, a circling boy: with whom your Numps, is so taken, that you may strip him of his clothes, if you will. I'll undertake to geld him for you; if you had but a surgeon, ready, to fear him. And mistress justice,
there, is the goodest woman! she does so love 'em all over, in terms of justice, and the style of authority, with her hood upright ‚Äî that I beseech you come away gentlemen, and see't.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: 'Slight, I would not lose it for the fair, what'll you do, Ned?

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: Why, stay here about for you, mistress Welborne must not be seen.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Do so, and find out a priest i'the mean time, I'll bring the licence. Lead, which way is't?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Here, sir, you are o'the backside o'the booth already, you may hear the noise.

div.head: Act. iv. scene. Iv.
div.stage: Knockhum. Nordern. Pvppy. Cutting. Whit. Edgvvorth. Qvarlous. Overdoo. Waspe. Bristle.

sp.p: Whit, bid Vall cutting continue the vapours for a lift, whit, for a lift.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: I'll ne mare, I'll ne mare, the eale's too meeghty.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: How now! my Galloway nag, the staggers? ha! Whit, gi' him a slit i'the forehead. Cheer up, man, a needle, and thread to stitch his ears. I'd cure him now an' i had it, with a little butter, and garlic, long-pepper, and grains. Where's my horn? I'll gi' him a mash, presently, shall take away this dizziness.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Why, where are you zurs? do you flinch, and leave us i'the zuds, now?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: I'll ne mare, i'is e'en as vull as a paipers bag, by my troth, I.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Do my Northern cloth shrink i'the wetting? ha?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Why, well said, old flea-bitten, thou'lt never tire, I see.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: they fall to their vapours, again. no, sir, but he may tire, if it please him.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Who told dee sho? that he vuld never teer, man?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: No matter who told him so, so long as he knows.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Nay, I know nothing, sir, pardon me there.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: They are at it still, sir, this they call vapours.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: He shall not pardon dee, captain, dou shalt not be pardoned. Pre'de shweete heart do not pardon him.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: 'Slight, I'll pardon him, an' i list, whosoever says nay to't.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Where's Numps? I miss him. here they continue their game of vapours, which is non sense. Every man to oppose the last man that spoke: whether it concerned him, or no.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Why, I say nay to't.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: O there he is!

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: To what do you say nay, sir?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: To any thing, whatsoever it is, so long as I do not like it.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Pardon me, little man, dou musht like it a little.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: No, he must not like it at all, sir, there you are i'the wrong.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: I tinke I be, he mushed not like it, indeed.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Nay, than he both must, and will like it, sir, for all you.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: If he have reason, he may like it, sir.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: By no meansh captain, upon reason, he may like nothing upon reason.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: I have no reason, nor I will hear of no reason, nor I will look for no reason, and he is an ass, that either knows any, or looks for't from me.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Yes, in some sense you may have reason, sir.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Ay, in some sense, I care not if I grant you.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Pardon me, thou oughtst to grant him nothing, in no shensh, if dou do love die shelf, angry man.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Why then, I do grant him nothing; and I have no sense.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: 'Tis true, thou hast no sense indeed.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: 'Slid, but I have sense, now I think on't better, and I will grant him any thing, do you see?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: He is i'the right, and does utter a sufficient vapour.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Nay, it is no sufficient vapour, neither, I deny that.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Then it is a sweet vapour.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: It may be a sweet vapour.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Nay, it is no sweet vapour, neither, sir, it stinks, and I'll stand to't.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Yes, I tinke it dosh shtink, captain. All vapour dosh shtink.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Nay, than it does not stink, sir, and it shall not stink.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: By your leave, it may, sir.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Ay, by my leave, it may stink, I know that.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Pardon me, thou knowesht nothing, it cannot by thy leave, angry man.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: How can it not?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Nay, never question him, for he is i'the right.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Yesh, I am I'd right, I confesh it, so ish de little man too.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: I'll have nothing confessed, that concerns me. I am not i'the right, nor never was i'the right, nor never will be i'the right, while I am in my right mind,

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Mind? why, here's no man minds you, sir,they drink again. nor any thing else.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Friend, will you mind this that we do?

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Call you this vapours? this is such beltching of quarrel, as I never heard. Will you mind your business, sir?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: You shall see, sir.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: I'll ne more, my waimb works too mickle with this anready.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Will you take that, master Wasp, that nobody should mind you?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Why? what ha' you to do? is't any matter to you?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: No, but methinks you should not be unminded, though,

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Nor, I won't be, now I think on't, do you hear, new acquaintance, does no man mind me, say you?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Yes, sir, every man here minds you, but how?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Nay, I care as little how, as you do, that was not my question.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: No, noting was ty question, tou art a learned man, and I am a valiant man, i'faith la, tou shalt speak for me, and I vill fight for tee.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Fight for him, whit? A gross vapour, he can fight for himself.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: It may be I can, but it may be, I will not, how then?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Why, than you may choose.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Why, and I'll choose whether I'll choose or no.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: I think you may, and 'tis true; and I allow it for a resolute vapour.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Nay, then, I do think you do not think, and it is no resolute vapour.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Yes, in some sort he may allow you.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: In no sort, sir, pardon me, I can allow him nothing. You mistake the vapour.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: He mistakes nothing, sir, in no sort.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Yes, I pre dee now, let him mistake.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: A turd i'your teeth, never pre dee me, for I will have nothing mistaken.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: they fall by the cares. turd, ha turd? A noisome vapour, strike whit.

sp.speaker: Ove.
sp.p: Why, gentlemen, why gentlemen, I charge you upon my authority, conserve the peace. In the King's name, and my husbands, put up your weapons, I shall be driven to commit you myself, else.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Why do you laugh, sir?

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Sir, you'll allow me my christian liberty. I may laugh, I hope.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: In some sort you may, and in some sort you may not, sir.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Nay in some sort, sir, he may neither laugh, nor hope, in this company.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Yes, than he may both laugh, and hope in any sort, an't please him.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Faith, and I will then, for it doth please me exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: No exceeding neither, sir.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: No, that vapour is too lofty.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I do not play well at your game of vapours, I am not very good at it, but ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Do you hear, sir? I would speak with you in circle? he draws a circle on the ground.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: In circle, sir? what would you with me in circle?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Can you lend me a piece, a Jacobus? in circle?

sp.speaker: Qva.
