sp.p: 'Slid, your circle will prove more costly than your vapours, then. Sir, no, I lend you none.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Your beard's not well turned up, sir.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: How rascal? are you playing with my beard? they draw all, and fight. I'll break circle with you.

sp.speaker: Pup. Nor.
sp.p: Gentlemen, gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Gather up, whit, gather up, whit, good vapours.

sp.speaker: Ove.
sp.p: What mean you? are you rebels? Gentlemen? shall I send out a sergeant at arms, or a writ o'rebellion, against you? I'll commit you upon my womanhood, for a riot, upon my justice-hood, if you persist.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Upon your justice-hood? Marry shite o'your hood, you'll commit? Spoken like a true justice of peace's wife, indeed, and a fine female lawyer! turd i'your teeth for a fee, now.

sp.speaker: Over.
sp.p: Why, Numps, in master Ouerdoo's name, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Good mistress Underdoo hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Over.
sp.p: Alas! poor Numps.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Alas! and why alas from you, I beseech you? or why poor Numps, goody rich? am I come to be pitied by your tuft taffeta now? why mistress, I knew Adam, the clerk, your husband, when he was Adam Scrivener, and writ for two pence a sheet, as high as he bears his head now, or you your hood, dame. What are you, sir? the watch comes in.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: We be men, and no infidels; what is the matter, here, and the noises? can you tell?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Heart, what ha' you to do? cannot a man quarrel in quietness? but he must be put out on't by you? what are you?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Why, we be his majesty's watch, sir.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Watch? 'sblood, you are a sweet watch, indeed. A body would think, and you watched well a nights, you should be contented to sleep at this time a day. Get you to your fleas, and your flocke-beds, you rogues, your kennels, and lie down close.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Down? yes, we will down, I warrant you, down with him in his majesty's name, down, down with him, and carry him away, to the pigeon-holes.

sp.speaker: Ove.
sp.p: I thank you honest friends, in the behalf o'the crown, and the peace, and in master Ouerdoo's name, for suppressing enormities.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Stay, Bristle, here ish a noder brash o'drunkards, but very quiet, special drunkards, will pay dee, five shillings very well. Take 'em to dee, in de graish of God: one of hem does change cloth, for ale in the fair, here, te toder ish a strong man, a mighty man, my lord mayor's man, and a wrestler. He has wrashled so long with the bottle, here, that the man with the beard, hash almosht streeke up hish heelsh.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: 'Slid, the clerk o'the market, has been to cry him all the fair over, here, for my lord's service.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Tere he ish, pre de taik him hensh, and make ty best on him. How now woman of shilk, vat ailsh ty sweet faish? art tou melancholy?

sp.speaker: Ove.
sp.p: A little distempered with these enormities; shall I entreat a courtesy of you, captain?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Entreat a hundred, velvet woman, I vill do it, shpeak out.

sp.speaker: Ove.
sp.p: I cannot with modesty speak it out, but ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: I vill do it, and more, and more, for dee. What Ursla, an't be bitch, an't be bawd and't be!

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: How now rascal? what roar you for? old pimp.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Here, put up de cloaks Ursh; de purchase, pre dee now, sweet Ursh, help dis good brave woman, to a Jordan, an't be.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: 'Slid call your captain Jordan to her, can you not?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Nay, pre dee leave die consheits, and bring the velvet woman to de ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: I bring her, hang her: heart must I find a common pot for every punk i'your purlieus?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: O good voordsh, Ursh, it ish a guest o'velvet, i'fait la.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Let her sell her hood, and buy a sponge, with a pox to her, my vessel, employed sir. I have but one, and 'tis the bottom of an old bottle. An honest proctor, and his wife, are at it, within, if she'll stay her time, so.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: As soon ash tou cansht shwet Ursh of a valiant man I tinke I am the patientsh man i'the world, or in all Smithfield.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: How now whit? close vapours, stealing your leaps? covering in corners, ha?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: No fait, captain, dough tou beesht a vishe man, die vit is a mile hence, now. I vas procuring a shmall courtesy, for a woman of fashion here.

sp.speaker: Ove.
sp.p: Yes, captain, though I am justice of peace's wife, I do love men of war, and the sons of the sword, when they come before my husband.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Say'st thou so filly? thou shalt have a leap presently, I'll horse thee myself, else.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Come, will you bring her in now? and let her talk her turn?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Gramercy good Ursh, I tank dee.

sp.speaker: Over.
sp.p: Master Overdoo shall thank her.

div.head: Act. iv. Scene. V.
div.stage: John. Win. Ursla. Knockhum. Whit. Overdoo. Ales.

sp.p: Good gammer Urs; win, and I, are exceedingly beholden to you, and to captain Jordan, and captain whit. Win, I'll be bold to leave you, i'this good company, win: for half an hour, or so win, while I go, and see how my matter goes forward, and if the puppets be perfect: and then I'll come and fetch you, win.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Will you leave me alone with two men, John?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Ay, they are honest gentlemen win, captain Jordan, and captain whit, they'll use you very civilly, win, God b'w'you, win.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: What's her husband gone?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: On his false, gallop, Urs, away.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: An' you be right bartholmew-birds, now show yourselves so: we are undone for want of foul i'the fair, here. Here will be Zekiel Edgworth, and three or four gallants, with him at night, and I ha' neither plover nor quail for 'em: persuade this between you two, to become a bird o'the game, while I work the velvet woman, within, (As you call her.)

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: I conceive thee, Urs! go thy ways, dost thou hear, whit? is't not pity, my delicate dark chestnut here; with the fine lean head, large forehead, round eyes, even mouth, sharp ears, long neck, thin crest, close withers, plain back, deep sides, short fillets, and full flanks: with a round belly, a plump but tocke, large thighs, knit knees, straight legs, short pasterns, smooth hooves, and short heels; should lead a dull honest woman's life, that might live the life of a lady?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Yes, by my fait, and trot, it is, captain: de honesht woman's life is a scurvy dull life, indeed, la.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: How, sir? is an honest woman's life a scurvy life?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Yes fait, sweet heart, believe him, de leefe of a bond. woman! but if dou vilt hearken to me, I vill make tee a freewoman, and a lady: dou shalt live like a lady, as te captain saish.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p:
Ay, and be honest too sometimes: have her wires, and
her tires, her green gowns, and velvet petticoats.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Ay, and ride to Ware and Rumford i'dy coash, she de players, be in love vit 'em; sup vit gallantsh, be drunk, and cost de noting.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Brave vapours!

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: And lie by twenty on 'em, if dou pleash sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: What, and be honest still, that were fine sport.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Tish common, sweet heart, tou mayest do it by my hand: it shall be justified to ty husband's faish, now: tou shalt be as honesht as the skin between his hornsh, la!

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Yes, and wear a dressing, top, and top-gallant, to compare with ere a husband on 'em all, for a foretop: it is the vapour of spirit in the wife, to cuckold, now adays; as it is the vapour of fashion, in the husband, not to suspect. Your prying cat-eyed-citizen, is an abominable vapour.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Lord, what a fool have I been!

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Mend then, and do every ting like a lady, hereafter, never know ty husband, from another man.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Nor any one man from another, but i'the dark.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Ay, and then it ish no dishgrash to know any man.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Help, help here.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: How now? what vapour's there?

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: O, you are a sweet ranger! and look well to your walks. Yonder is your punk of Turnbull, ramping ales, has fallen upon the poor gentlewoman within, and pulled her hood over her ears,Alice enters, beating he justice's wife. and her hair through it.

sp.speaker: Ove.
sp.p: Help, help, i'the King's name.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.p: A mischief on you, they are such as you are, that undo us, and take our trade from us, with your tuft-taffata haunches.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: How now Alice!

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.p: The poor common whores can ha' no traffic, for the privy rich ones; your caps and hoods of velvet, call away our customers, and lick the fat from us.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Peace you foul ramping jade, you ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.p: Od's foot, you bawd in grease, are you talking?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Why, Alice, I say.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.p: Thou sow of Smithfield, thou.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Thou tripe of Turnbull.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Cat-a-mountaine-vapours! ha!

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: You know where you were tawed lately, both lashed, and slashed you were in Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.p: Ay, by the same token, you rid that week, and broke out the bottom o'the cart, Night-tub.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Why, lion face! ha! do you know who I am? shall I tear ruff, slit waistcoat, make rags of petticoat? ha! go to, vanish, for fear of vapours. Whit, a kick, whit, in the parting vapour. Come brave woman, take a good heart, thou shalt be a lady, too.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Yes fait, day shall all both be ladies, and write madam. I vill do't myself for dem. Do, is the vord, and d is the middle letter of madam, d d, put 'em together, and make deeds, without which, all words are alike, la.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Ursla, take 'em in, open thy wardrobe, and fit 'em to their calling. Greene-gownes, crimson-petticoats, green women! my lord mayor's green women! guests o'the game, true bred. I'll provide you a coach, to take the air, in.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: But do you think you can get one?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: O, they are as common as wheelbarrows, where there are great dunghills. Every pettifogger's wife, has 'em, for first he buys a coach, that he may marry, and then he marries that he may be made cuckold in't: for if their wives ride not to their cuckolding, they do 'em no credit. Hide, and be hidden; ride, and be ridden, says the vapour of experience.

div.head: Act. iv. scene. Vi.
div.stage: Troble-all. Knockhum. Whit. Qvarlous. Edgvvorth. Bristle. Waspe. Haggise. Justice. Busy. Pvre-craft.

sp.p: By what warrant does it say so?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Ha! Mad child o'the piepowders, art thou there? fill us a fresh can, Urs, we may drink together.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: I may not drink without a warrant, captain.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: 'Sblood, thou'll not stale without a warrant, shortly. Whit, give me pen, ink and paper. I'll draw him a warrant presently.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: It must be justice Ouerdoo's?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: I know, man, fetch the drink, whit.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: I pre dee now, be very brief, captain; for de new ladies stay for dee.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: O, as brief as can be, here 'tis already. Adam Overdoo.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Why, now, I'll pledge you, captain.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Drink it off. I'll come to thee, anon, again.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Well, sir. You are now discharged:Quarlous to the cutpurse ‚ñ™ beware of being spied, hereafter.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Sir, will it please you, enter in here, at Ursla's; and take
part of a silken gown, a velvet petticoat, or a wrought smock; I am promised such: and I can spare any gentleman a moiety.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Keep it for your companions in beastliness, I am none of 'em, sir. If I had not already forgiven you a greater trespass, or thought you yet worth my beating, I would instruct your manners, to whom you made your offers. But go your ways, talk not to me, the hangman is only fit to discourse with you; the hand of beadle is too merciful a punishment for your trade of life. I am sorry I employed this fellow; for he thinks me such: facinus quos inquinat, aequat. But, it was for sport. And would I make it serious, the getting of this licence is nothing to me, without other circumstances concur. I do think how impertinently I labour, if the word be not mine, that the ragged fellow marked: and what advantage I have given Ned Win-wife in this time now, of working her, though it be mine. He'll go near to form to her what a debauched rascal I am, and fright her out of all good conceit of me: I should do so by him, I am sure, if I had the opportunity. But my hope is in her temper, yet; and it must needs be next to despair, that is grounded on any part of a woman's discretion. I would give by my troth, now, all I could spare (To my clothes, and my sword) to meet my tattered soothsayer again, who was my judge i'the question, to know certainly whose word he has damned or saved. For, till then, I live but under a reprieve. I must seek him. Who be these?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Ent Wasp with the officers. sir, you are a Welsh cuckold, and a prating runt, and no constable.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: You say very well. Come put in his leg in the middle roundel, and let him hole there.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: You stink of leeks, metheglin, and cheese. You rogue.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Why, what is that to you, if you sit sweetly in the stocks in the mean time? if you have a mind to stink too, your breeches sit close enough to your bum. Sit you merry, sir.

sp.speaker: Qva
sp.p: How now, Numps?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: It is no matter, how; pray you look off.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Nay I'll not offend you, Numps. I thought you had sat there to be seen.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: And to be sold, did you not? pray you mind your business, an' you have any.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Cry you mercy, Numps. Does your leg lie high enough?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: How now, neighbour Haggise, what says justice Ouerdo's worship, to the other offenders?

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: Why, he says just nothing, what should he say? Or where should he say? He is not to be found, man. He ha' not been seen i'the fair, here, all this livelong day, never since seven o'clock i' the morning. His clerks know not what to think on't. There is no court of pie-poulders yet. Here they be returned.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: What shall be done with 'em, then? in your discretion?

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: I think we were best put 'em in the stocks, in discretion (There they will be safe in discretion) for the valour of an hour, or such a thing, till his worship come. as they open the stocks, Wasp puts his shoe on his hand, and slips it in for his leg.

sp.speaker: Bri
sp.p: It is but a hole matter, if we do, neighbour Haggise, come, sir, here is company for you, heave up the stocks.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: I shall put a trick upon your Welsh diligence, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Put in your leg, sir.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: What, rabbi busy! is he come?

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: I do obey thee, the lion may roar, but he cannot bite. they bring Busy, and put him in. I am glad to be thus separated from the heathen of the land, and put a part in the stocks, for the holy cause.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: What are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: One that rejoiceth in his affliction, and sitteth here to prophesy, the destruction of fairs and may-games, wakes, and whitson-ales, and doth sigh and groan for the reformation, of these abuses.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: And do you sigh, and groan too, or rejoice in your affliction?

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: I do not feel it, I do not think of it, it is a thing without me. Adam, thou art above these batteries, these contumelies. In te manca rvit fortuna, as thy friend Horace says; thou art one, quem neque pauperies, neque mors, neque vincula terrent,. And therefore as another friend of thine says, (I think it be thy friend Persius) non te quaesiueris extra.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: What's here! A Stoic i'the stocks? the fool is turned philosopher.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Friend, I will leave to communicate my spirit with you, if I hear any more of those superstitious relics, those lists of Latin, the very rags of Rome, and patches of popery.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Nay, an you begin to quarrel, gentlemen, I'll leave you. I ha' paid for quarrelling too lately: look you, a device,he gets out. but shifting in a hand for a foot. God b'w'you.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Wilt thou then leave thy brothers in tribulation?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: For this once, sir.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Thou art a halting neutral stay him there, stop him: that will not endure the heat of persecution.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: How now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: He is fled, he is fled, and dares not sit it out.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: What, has he made an escape, which way? follow, neighbour Haggise.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O me! in the stocks! have the wicked prevailed?

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Peace religious sister, it is my calling, comfort yourself, an extraordinary calling, and done for my better standing, my surer standing, hereafter.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: By whose warrant, by whose warrant, this? the madman enters.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: O, here's my man! dropped in, I looked for.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O good sir, they have set the faithful, here to be wondered at; and provided holes, for the holy of the land.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Had they warrant for it? showed they justice Ouerdoo's hand? if they had no warrant, they shall answer it.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Sure you did not lock the stocks sufficiently, neighbour Toby!

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: No! see if you can lock 'em better.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: They are very sufficiently locked, and truly, yet some thing is in the matter.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: True, your warrant is the matter that is in question, by what warrant?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Mad man, hold your peace, I will put you in his room else, in the very same hole, do you see?

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: How! is he a madman!

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Show me justice Ouerdoo's warrant. I obey you.

sp.speaker: Hag.
sp.p: You are a mad fool, hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: shows his can. in justice Ouerdoo's name, I drink to you, and here's my warrant.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Alas poor wretch! how it earns my heart for him!

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: If he be mad, it is in vain to question him. I'll try though, friend: there was a gentlewoman, showed you two names, some hour since, Argalus and Palemon, to mark in a book, which of 'em was it you marked?

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: I mark no name, but Adam Overdoo, that is the name of names, he only is the sufficient magistrate; and that name I reverence, show it me.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: This fellows mad indeed: I am further off, now, then afore.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: I shall not breathe in peace, till I have made him some amends.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Well, I will make another use of him, is come in my head: I have a nest of beards in my trunk, one some thing like his.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: the watchmen come back again. The madman fights with 'em, and they leave open the stocks. this mad fool has made me that I know not whether I I have locked the stocks or no, I think I locked 'em.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Take Adam Overdoo in your mind, and fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: 'Slid, madness itself, hold thy peace, and take that.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Strikest thou without a warrant? take thou that.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: We are delivered by miracle; fellow in fetters, let us not refuse the means, this madness was of the spirit: the malice of the enemy hath mocked itself.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p:
Mad do they call him! the world is mad in error, but he is mad in truth: I love him o'the sudden, (The cunning man said all true) and shall love him more, and more. How well it becomes a man to be mad in truth! O, that I might be his yoke-fellow, and be mad with him, what a many should we draw to
madness in truth, with us!

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: How now! all scaped? where's the woman? it is witchcraft! the watch missing them are affrighted. her velvet hat is a witch, of my conscience, or my key! t'one. The madman was a devil, and I am an ass; so bless me, my place, and mine office.

div.head: Act. v. scene. i.
div.stage: Lanthorne. Filcher. Sharkwel.

sp.p: Well, luck and saint Bartholmew; out with the sign of our invention, in the name of wit, and do you beat the drum, the while; all the fowl i'the fair, I mean, all the dirt in Smithfield, (That's one of master Littlewit's carwhitchets now) will be thrown at our banner today, if the matter does not please the people. O the motions, that I lantern Leatherhead have given light to, i' my time, since my master Pod died! Jerusalem was a stately thing; and so was Niniveh, and the city of Norwich, and Sodom and Gomorrah;Pod was a master of motions before him. with the rising o'the prentices; and pulling down the bawdy houses there, upon Shrove-tuesday; but the gunpowder-plot, there was a get-penny! I have presented that to an eighteen, or twenty pence audience, nine times in an afternoon. Your home-born projects prove ever the best, they are so easy, and familiar, they put too much learning i'their things now adays: and that I fear will be the spoil o'this. Littlewit? I say, mickle-wit! if not too mickle! look to your gathering there, good man filcher.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: I warrant you, sir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: And there come any gentlefolks, take two pence a piece, Sharkwell.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: I warrant you, sir, three pence, an'we can.

div.head: Act. v. scene. Ii.
div.stage: Justice. Win-wife. Grace. Qvarlovs. Pvre-craft.

sp.p: This later disguise, I have borrowed of a porter, shall carry me out to all my great and good ends;the justice comes in like a porter. which however interrupted, were never destroyed in me: neither is the hour of my severity yet come, to reveal myself, wherein cloudlike, I will break out in rain, and hail, lightning, and thunder, upon the head of enormity. Two main works I have to prosecute: first, one is to invent some satisfaction for the poor, kind wretch, who is out of his wits for my sake, and yonder I see him coming, I will walk aside, and project for it.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I wonder where Tom quarlous is, that he returns not, it may be he is struck in here to seek us.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: See, here's our madman again.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: I have made myself as like him, as his gown, and cap will give me leave. Quarlous in the habit of the madman is mistaken by mistressPure-craft.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Sir, I love you, and would be glad to be mad with you in truth.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: How! my widow in love with a madman?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Verily, I can be as mad in spirit, as you.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: By whose warrant? leave your canting. Gentlewoman, have I found you? (Save ye, quit ye, and multiply ye) where's your book? he desires to see the book of mistress grace.'twas a sufficient name I marked, let me see't, be not afraid to show't me.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: What would you with it, sir?

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Mark it again, and again, at your service.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Here it is, sir, this was it you marked.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Palemon? fare you well, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: How, Palemon!

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Yes faith, he has discovered it to you, now, and therefore 'twere vain to disguise it longer, I am yours, sir, by the benefit of your fortune.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: And you have him mistress, believe it, that shall never give you cause to repent her benefit, but make you rather to think that in this choice, she had both her eyes.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: I desire to put it to no danger of protestation.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Palemon, the word, and Win-wife the man?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Good sir, vouchsafe a yoke-fellow in your madness, shun not one of the sanctified sisters, that would draw with you, in truth.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Away, you are a herd of hypocritical proud ignorants, rather wild, then mad. Fitter for woods, and the society of beasts than houses, and the congregation of men. You are the second part of the society of canters, outlaws to order and discipline, and the only privileged church-robbers of Christendom. Let me alone. Palemon, the word, and Win-wife the man?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: I must uncover myself unto him, or I shall never enjoy him, for all the cunning men's promises. Good sir, hear me, I am worth six thousand pound, my love to you, is become my rack, I'll tell you all, and the truth: since you hate the hypocrisy of the particoloured brotherhood. These seven years, I have been a wilful holy widow, only to draw feasts, and gifts from my entangled suitors: I am also by office, an assisting sister of the deacons, and a devourer, in stead of a distributer of the alms. I am a special maker of marriages for our decayed brothers, with our rich widows; for a third part of their wealth, when they are married, for the relief of the poor elect: as also our poor handsome young virgins, with our wealthy bachelors, or widowers; to make them steal from their husbands, when I have confirmed them in the faith, and got all put into their custodies. And if I ha' not my bargain, they may sooner turn a scolding drab, in to a silent minister, then make me leave pronouncing reprobation, and damnation unto them. Our elder, Zeal-of-the-land, would have had me, but I know him to be the capital knave of the land, making himself rich, by being made feoffee in trust to deceased brothers, and cozening their heirs, by swearing the absolute gift of their inheritance. And thus having eased my conscience, and uttered my heart, with the tongue of my love: enjoy all my deceits together. I beseech you. I should not have revealed this to you, but that in time I think you are mad, and I hope you'll think me so too, sir?

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p:
Stand aside, I'll answer you, presently. he consider with himself of it. why should not I marry this six thousand pound, now I think on't? and a good trade too, that she has beside, ha? The tother wench, Win-wife, is sure of; there's no expectation for me there! here I may make myself some saver, yet, if she continue mad, there's the question. It is money that I want, why should I not marry the money, when 'tis offered me? I have a licence and all, it is but razing out one name, and putting in another. There's no playing with a man's fortune! I am resolved! I were truly mad, an' I would not! well, come your ways, follow me, an' you will be mad,
He takes her along with him.
The justice calls him. I'll show you a warrant!

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Most zealously, it is that I zealously desire.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Sir, let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: By whose warrant?

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: The warrant that you tender, and respect so; justice Ouerdoo's! I am the man, friend Trouble-all, though thus disguised (As the careful magistrate ought) for the good of the republic, in the fair, and the weeding out of enormity. Do you want a house or meat, or drink, or clothes? speak whatsoever it is, it shall be supplied you, what want you?

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Nothing but your warrant.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: My warrant? for what?

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: To be gone, sir.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Nay, I pray thee stay, I am serious, and have not many words, nor much time to exchange with thee; think what may do thee good.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Your hand and seal, will do me a great deal of good; nothing else in the whole fair, that I know.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: If it were to any end, thou shouldst have it willingly.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Why, it will satisfy me, that's end enough, to look on; an' you will not give it me, let me go.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Alas! thou shalt ha' it presently: I'll but step into the scriveners,the justice goes out. hereby, and bring it. Do not go away.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Why, this mad man's shape, will prove a very fortunate one, I think! can a ragged robe produce these effects? if this be the wise justice, and he bring me his hand, I shall go near to make some use on't. He is come already!

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: and returns. look thee! here is my hand and seal, Adam Overdoo, if there be any thing to be written, above in the paper, that thou wantest now, or at any time hereafter; think on't; it is my deed, I deliver it so, can your friend write?

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: he urgeth mistress Purecraft.her hand for a witness, and all is well.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Why should not I ha' the conscience, to make this a bond of a thousand pound? now, or what I would else?

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Look you, there it is; and I deliver it as my deed again.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Let us now proceed in madness.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: he takes her in with him. well, my conscience is much eased; I ha' done my part, though it doth him no good, yet Adam hath offered satisfaction! The sting is removed from hence: poor man, he is much altered with his affliction, it has brought him low! Now, for my other work, reducing the young man (I have followed so long in love) from the brink of his bane, to the centre of safety. Here, or in some such like vain place, I shall be sure to find him. I will wait the good time.

div.head: Act. v. scene. Iv.
div.stage: Cokes. Shakrwel. Justice. Filcher. John. Lantern.

sp.p: How now? what's here to do? friend, art thou the master of the monuments?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: 'Tis a motion, an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: My fantastical brother in law, master Bartholmew Cokes!

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: A motion, what's that? he reads the bill. the ancient modern history of hero, and Leander, otherwise called the touchstone of true love, with as true a trial of friendship, between Damon, and Pithias, two faithful friends o'the Bankside? pretty i'faith, what's the meaning on't? is't an interlude? or what is't?

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: Yes sir, please you come near, we'll take your money within.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Back with these children;the boys o'the fair follow him. they do so follow me up and down.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: By your leave, friend.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: You must pay, sir, an' you go in.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Who, I? I perceive thou knowest not me: call the master o'the motion.

sp.speaker: Sha
sp.p: What, do you not know the author, fellow filcher? you must take no money of him; he must come in gratis: mr. Littlewit is a voluntary; he is the author.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Peace, speak not too loud, I would not have any notice taken, that I am the author, till we see how it passes.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Master Littlewit, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Master Cokes! you are exceeding well met: what, in your doublet, and hose, without a cloak, or a hat?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: I would I might never stir, as I am an honest man, and by that fire; I have lost all i'the fair, and all my acquaintance too; didst thou meet anybody that I know, master Littlewit? my man Numps, or my sister Overdoo, or mistress grace? pray thee master Littlewit, lend me some money to see the interlude, here. I'll pay thee again, as I am a gentleman. If thou'lt but carry me home, I have money enough there.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: O, sir, you shall command it, what, will a crown serve you?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: I think it well, what do we pay for coming in, fellows?

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: Two pence, sir.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Two pence? there's twelve pence, friend; nay, I am a gallant, as simple as I look now; if you see me with my man about me, and my artillery, again.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Your man was i'the stocks, e'en now, sir.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Who, Numps?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Yes faith.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: For what i' saith, I am glad of that; remember to tell me on't anon; I have enough, now! What manner of matter is this, Mr. Littlewit ? What kind of actors ha' you? Are they good actors?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Pretty youths, sir, all children both old and young, here's the master of 'em ‚Äî

sp.speaker: (Lan.
sp.p: Leatherhead whispers to Littlewit.call me not Leatherhead, but lantern.)

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Master Lantern, that gives light to the business,

sp.speaker: Cok ‚ñ™
sp.p: In good time, sir, I would fain see 'em, I would be glad drink with the young company; which is the tiring-house?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Troth, sir, our tiring-house is somewhat little, we are but beginners, yet, pray pardon us; you cannot go upright in't.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: No? not now my hat is off? what would you have done with me, if you had had me, feather, and all, as I was once today? Have you none of your pretty impudent boys, now; to bring stools, fill tobacco, fetch ale, and beg money, as they have at other houses? let me see some o'your actors.

sp.speaker: Ion.
sp.p: Show him 'em, show him 'em. Master Lantern, this is a gentleman, that is a favourer of the quality.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Ay, the fauouring of this licentious quality, is the consumption of many a young gentleman; a pernicious enormity.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: What, do they live in baskets?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: he brings them out in a basket. they do lie in a basket, sir, they are o'the small players.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: These be players minors, indeed. Do you call these players?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: They are actors, sir, and as good as any, none dispraised, for dumb shows: indeed, I am the mouth of 'em all!

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Thy mouth will hold 'em all. I think, one tailor, would go near to beat all this company, with a hand bound behind him.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Ay, and eat 'em all, too, an' they were in cakebread.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: I thank you for that, master Littlewit, a good jest! which is your Burbage now?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: What mean you by that, sir?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Your best actor. Your field?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Good i'faith! you are even with me, sir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p:
This is he, that acts young Leander, sir. He is extremely beloved of the womankind, they do so affect his action, the
green gamesters, that come here, and this is lovely hero; this with the beard, Damon; and this pretty Pythias: this is the ghost of King Dionysius in the habit of a scrivener: as you shall see anon, at large.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Well they are a civil company, I like 'em for that; they offer not to fleer, nor gear, nor break jests, as the great players do: and then, there goes not so much charge to the feasting of 'em, or making 'em drunk, as to the other, by reason of their littleness. Do they use to play perfect? Are they never flustered?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: No, sir. I thank my industry, and policy for it; they are as well governed a company, though I say it ‚Äî and here is young Leander, is as proper an actor of his inches; and shakes his head like an ostler.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: But do you play it according to the printed book? I have read that.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: By no means, sir.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: No? How then?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: A better way, sir, that is too learned, and poetical for our audience; what do they know what Hellespont is? Guilty of true love's blood? or what Abydos is? or the other Sestos hight?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Thou'rt i'the right, I do not know myself.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: No, I have entreated master Littlewit, to take a little pains to reduce it to a more familiar strain for our people.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: How, I pray thee, good Mr. Littlewit?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: It pleases him to make a matter of it, sir. But there is no such matter I assure you: I have only made it a little easy, and modern for the times, sir, that's all; as, for the Hellespont I imagine our Thames here; and then Leander, I make a dyer's son, about puddle-wharf: and Hero a wench o'the Bankside, who going over one morning, to old Fish-street; Leander spies her land at Trigsstayer's, and falls in love with her: now do I introduce Cupid, having metamorphosed himself into a drawer, and he strikes hero in love with a pint of sherry, and other pretty passages there are, o'the friendship, that will delight you, sir, and please you of judgement.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: I'll be sworn they shall; I am in love with the actors already, and I'll be allied to them presently. (They respect gentlemen, these fellows) Hero shall be my fairing: but, which of my fayrings? (Le' me see) i'faith, my fiddle! and Leander my fiddlestick: then Damon, my drum; and Pythias, my pipe and the ghost of Dionysius, my hobby-horse. All fitted.

div.head: Act. v. scene iv.
div.stage: To them Win-wife. Grace. Knockhum. Whitt. Edgvvorth. Win. mistress Overdoo. And to them wasp.

sp.p: Look yonder's your Cokes gotten in among his playfellows; I thought we could not miss him, at such a spectacle.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Let him alone, he is so busy, he will never spy us.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Nay, good sir.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Cokes is handling the puppets.I warrant thee, I will not hurt her, fellow; what dost think me uncivil? I pray thee be not jealous: I am towards a wife.

sp.speaker: Ioh ‚ñ™
sp.p: Well good master Lantern, make ready to begin, that I may fetch my wife, and look you be perfect, you undo me else, i'my reputation.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I warrant you sir, do not you breed too great an expectation of it, among your friends: that's the only hurter of these things.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: I'll stay here, and see; pray thee let me see.

sp.speaker: Win-vv.
sp.p: How diligent and troublesome he is!

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: The place becomes him, methinks .

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: My ward, mistress grace in the company of a stranger? I doubt I shall be compelled to discover myself, before my time!

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: Two pence a piece gentlemen, an excellent motion.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: the doorkeepers speak. shall we have fine fireworks, and good vapours!

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Yes captain, and waterworks, too.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: I pree dee, take a care o'dy shmall lady, there, Edgworth; I will look to dish tall lady myself.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Welcome gentlemen, welcome gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Predee, mashter o'de monshtersh, help a very sick lady, here, to a chair, to shit in.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Presently, sir.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: they bring mistress Overdoo a chair. good fait now, Ursla's ale, and aquavitae ish to blame for't; shit down sweet heart, shit down ‚ñ™ and shleep a little.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Madam, you are very welcome hither.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Yes, and you shall see very good vapours.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Here is my care come! I like to see him in so good company;by Edgeworth. and yet I wonder that persons of such fashion, should resort hither!

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: This is a very private house, madam. the cutpurse courts mistress Littlewit .

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Will it please your ladyship sit, madam?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Yes goodman. They do so all to be madam me, I think they think me a very lady!

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: What else madam?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Must I put off my mask to him?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: O, by no means.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: How would my husband know me, then?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Husband? an idle vapour; he must not know you, nor you him; there's the true vapour.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Yes, I will observe more of this: is this a lady, friend?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: I and „Äà‚óä„Äâ is another lady, sweet heart; if dou hashed a mind to 'em give me twelve pence from tee, and dou shalt have eder-oder on 'em!

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: I? This will prove my chiefest enormity: I will follow this.

sp.speaker: Edg,
sp.p: Is not this a finer life, lady, than to be clogged with a husband?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Yes, a great deal. When will they begin, trow? in the name o'the motion?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: By and by madam, they stay but for company.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Do you hear, puppet. Master, these are tedious vapours; when begin you?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: We stay but for master Littlewit, the author, who is gone for his wife; and we begin presently.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: That's I, that's I.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: That was you, lady; but now you are no such poor thing.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Hang the author's wife, a running vapour! here be ladies, will stay for never a Delia o 'em all.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: But hear me now, here ish one o'de ladish, a shleep, stay till she but vake man.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: How now friends? what's here to do?

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: Two pence a piece, sir, the best motion, in the fair. the doorkeepers again.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: I believe you lie; if you do, I'll have my money again, and beat you.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Numps is come!

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Did you see a master of mine, come in here, a tall young squire of Harrow o'the hill; master Bartholmew Cokes?

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: I think there be such a one, within.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Look he be, you were best: but it is very likely: I wonder I found him not at all the rest. I ha' been at the eagle, and the black wolf, and the bull with the five legs, and two pizzles; (He was a calf at Uxbridge fair, two years ago) and at the dogs that dance the morris, and the hare of the taber; and missed him at all these! Sure this must needs be some fine sight, that holds him so, if it have him.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Come, come, are you ready now?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Presently, sir.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Heyday, he's at work in his doublet, and hose; do you hear, sir? are you employed? that you are bare headed, and so busy?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Hold your peace, Numpes; you ha' been i'the stocks, I hear.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Does he know that? nay, than the date of my authority is out; I must think no longer to reign, my government is at an end. He that will correct another, must want fault in himself.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: Sententious Numps! I never heard so much from him, before.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Sure, master Littlewit will not come; please you take your place, sir, we'll begin.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: I pray thee do, mine ears long to be at it; and my eyes too. O Numps, i'the stocks, Numps? where's your sword, Numps?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: I pray you intend your game, sir, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Well then, we are quit for all. Come, sit down, Numps; I'll interpret to thee: did you see mistress grace? it's no matter, neither, now I think on't, tell me anon.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: A great deal of love, and care, he expresses.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Alas! would you have him to express more than he has? that were tyranny.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Peace, ho; now, now.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Gentles, that no longer your expectations may wander,
Behold our chief actor, amorous Leander.
With a great deal of cloth, lapped about him like a scarf,
For he yet serves his father, a dyer at puddle wharf,
Which place we'll make bold with, to call it our Abydos,
As the Bankside is our Sestos, and let it not be denied us.
Now, as he is beating, to make the dye take the fuller,
Who chances to come by, but fair hero, in a sculler;
And seeing Leander's naked leg, and goodly calf,
Cast at him, from the boat, a sheep's eye, and a half.
Now she is landed, and the sculler come back;
By and by, you shall see what Leander doth lack.

sp.speaker: Pup. L.
sp.p: Cole, coal, old coal.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: That is the sculler's name without control.

sp.speaker: Pup. L.
sp.p: Cole, coal, I say, coal.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: We do hear you.

sp.speaker: Pup. L.
sp.p: Old coal.

sp.speaker: Lan
sp.p: Old coal? Is the dyer turned collier? how do you sell?

sp.speaker: Pup. L.
sp.p: A pox o'your manners, kiss my hole here, and smell.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Kiss your hole, and smell? there's manners indeed.

sp.speaker: Pup. L.
sp.p: Why, coal, I say, coal.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: It's the sculler you need!

sp.speaker: Pup. L.
sp.p: Ay, and be hanged.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Be hanged; look you yonder,
Old coal, you must go hang with master Leander.

sp.speaker: Pup. c.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Pup. L.
sp.p: Here, coal, what fairest of fairs, was that fare, that thou landedst but now a trigsstayres?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: What was that, fellow? Pray thee tell me, I scarce understand 'em.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Leander does ask, sir, what fairest of fairs,
Was the fare they landed, but now, at Trigsstayer's?

sp.speaker: Pup. c.
sp.p: It is lovely hero.

sp.speaker: Pup. L.
sp.p: Nero?

sp.speaker: Pup. c.
sp.p: No, hero.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: It is hero.
Of the Bankside, he saith ‚ñ™ to tell you truth without erring,
Is come over into Fish-street to eat some fresh herring.
Leander says no more, but as fast as he can,
Gets on all his best clothes; and will after to the swan.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Most admirable good, is't not?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Stay, sculler.

sp.speaker: Pup. c.
sp.p: What say you?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: You must stay for Leander, and carry him to the wench.

sp.speaker: Pup. c.
sp.p: You rogue, I am no pandar.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: He says he is no pandar. 'tis a fine language; I understand it, now.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Are you no pandar, goodman Cole? here's no man says you are, you'll grow a hot coal, it seems, pray you stay for your fare.

sp.speaker: Pup. c.
sp.p: Will he come away?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: Pup. c.
sp.p: I'd ha' him come away.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: Would you ha' Leander come away? why pray sir, stay.
You are angry, goodman Cole; I believe the fair maid
Came over w' you of trust: tell us sculler, are you paid.

sp.speaker: Pup. c.
sp.p: Yes goodman Hog-rubber, of Pickt-hatch.

sp.speaker: Lav:
sp.p: How, Hog-rubber, of Pickt-hatch?

sp.speaker: Pup. c.
sp.p: I Hog-rubber of Pickt-hatch. Take you that.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: O, my head! the puppet strikes him over the pate

sp.speaker: Pup. c.
sp.p: Harm watch, harm catch.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Harm watch, harm catch, he says: very good i' faith, the sculler had like to ha' knocked you, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Yes, but that his fare called him away.

sp.speaker: Pup. L.
sp.p: Row apace, row apace, row, row, row, row, row.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: You are knavishly loaden, sculler, take heed where you go.

sp.speaker: Pup. c.
sp.p: Knave i' your face, goodman rogue.

sp.speaker: Pup. l
sp.p: Row, row, row, row, row, row.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: He said knave i' your face, friend.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I sir, I heard him. But there's no talking to these watermen, they will ha' the last word

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: God's my life! I am not allied to the sculler, yet; he shall be dauphin my boy. But my fiddlestick does fiddle in and out too much; I pray thee speak to him, on't: tell him, I would have him tarry in my sight, more.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I pray you be content; you'll have enough on him, sir.

lg.l: Now gentles, I take it, here is none of you so stupid,
But that you have heard of a little god of love, called Cupid.
Who out of kindness to Leander, hearing he but (Awe her,
This present day and hour, doth turn himself to a drawer.
And because, he would have their first meeting to be merry,
He strikes hero in love to him, with a pint of sherry.
Which he tells her ‚ñ™ from amorous Leander is sent her,
Pup. Leander goes into mistress Hero's room who after him, into the room of hero, doth venture.

sp.speaker: Pup. io:
sp.p: A pint of sack, score a pint of sack, i'the coney.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Sack? you said but e'en now it should be sherry.

sp.speaker: Pup. io:
sp.p: Why so it is; sherry, sherry, sherry.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Sherry, sherry, sherry. By my troth he makes me merry. I must have a name for Cupid, too. Let me see, thou mightst help me now, an' thou wouldst, Numps, at a dead lift, but thou art dreaming of the stocks, still! Do not think on't, I have forgotten it: 'tis but a nine days' wonder, man; let it not trouble thee.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: I would the stocks were about your neck, sir; condition I hung by the heels in them, till the wonder were off from you, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Well said resolute Numps: but hark you friend, where is the friendship, all this while, between my drum, Damon; and my pipe, Pythias?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: You shall see by and by, sir?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: You think my hobby-horse is forgotten, too; no, I'll see ‚ñ™ 'em all enact before I go; I shall not know which to love best, else

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: This gallant has interrupting vapours, troublesome vapours, Whitt, puff with him.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: No, I pre dee, captain, let him alone. He is a child i' faith, la' .

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Now gentles, to the friends, who in number, are two,
And lodged in that alehouse, in which fair hero does do.
Damon (For some kindness done him the last week)
Is come fair hero, in Fish-street, this morning to seek:
Pythias does smell the knavery of the meeting,
And now you shall see their true friendly greeting.

sp.speaker: Pup. Pi.
sp.p: You whoremasterly slave, you

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Whoremasterly slave, you? very friendly, and familiar, that.

sp.speaker: Pup. Da.
sp.l: Whoremaster i'thy face,
Thou hast lain with her thyself, I'll prove't i'this place.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Damon says Pythias has lain with her, himself, he'll prove't in this place.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: They are whoremasters both, sir, that's a plain case.

sp.speaker: Pup. Pi.
sp.p: You lie, like a rogue.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Do I lie, like a rogue?

sp.speaker: Pup. Pi.
sp.p: A pimp, and a scab.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: A pimp, and a scab?
I say between you, you have both but one drab.

sp.speaker: Pup. Da.
sp.p: You lie again.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Do I lie again?

sp.speaker: Pup. Da.
sp.p: Like a rogue again.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Like a rogue again?

sp.speaker: Pup. Pi.
sp.p: And you are a pimp, again.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: And you are a pimp again, he says.

sp.speaker: Pup. Da.
sp.p: And a scab, again.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: And a scab again, he says.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And I say again, you are both whoremasters again,they fight.
And you have both but one drab again.

sp.speaker: Pup. Da. Pi.
sp.p: Dost thou, dost thou, dost thou?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: What, both at once?

sp.speaker: Pup. P.
sp.p: Down with him, Damon

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: Pink his guts, Pythias ‚ñ™

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: What, so malicious?
Will ye murder me, masters both, i' mine own house?

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Ho! well acted my drum, well acted my pipe, well acted still.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Well acted, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Hold, hold your hands

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Ay, both your hands, for ‚ñ™ my sake! for you ha' both done well.

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: Gramercy pure Pythias.

sp.speaker: Pup. P.
sp.p: Gramercy, dear Damon.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Gramercy to you both, my pipe, and my drum.

sp.speaker: Pup. P. D.
sp.p: Come now we'll together to breakfast to hero.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: 'Tis well, you can now go to breakfast to hero, you have given many breakfast, with a hone and honero.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: How is't friend, ha' they hurt thee?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: O no!
Between you and I sir, we do but make show.
Thus gentles you perceive, without any denial,
'Twixt Damon and Pythias here, friendships true trial.
Though hourly they quarrel thus, and roar each with other,
They fight you no more, than does brother with brother.
But friendly together, at the next man they meet,
They let fly their anger as here you might see't.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Well, we have seen't, and thou hast felt it, whatsoever thou sayest, what's next? what's next?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: This while young Leander, with fair hero is drinking,
And hero grown drunk, to any man's thinking!
Yet was it not three pints of sherry could flaw her.
till Cupid distinguished like Jonas the drawer,
From under his apron, where his lechery lurks,
Put love in her sack. Now mark how it works.

sp.speaker: Pup. H.
sp.l: O Leander Leander, my dear my dear Leander,
I'll for ever be thy goose, so thou'lt be my gander

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Excellently well said, fiddle, she'll ever be his goose, so he'll be her gander: was't not so?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Yes, sir, but mark his answer, now:

sp.speaker: Pup. L¬∑
sp.l: And sweetest of geese, before I go to bed,
I'll swim o'er the Thames, my goose, thee to tread.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Brave! he will swim o'er the Thames, and tread his goose, too night, he says.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Ay, peace, sir, they'll be angry, if they hear you eavesdropping, now they are setting their match.

sp.speaker: Pup. L.
sp.p: But lest the Thames should be dark, my goose, my dear friend, let thy window be provided of a candle's end.

sp.speaker: Pup. H.
sp.p: Fear not my gander, I protest, I should handle my matters very ill, if I had not a whole candle.

sp.speaker: Pup. L.
sp.p: Well then, look to't, and kiss me to boot.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Now, here come the friends again, Pythias, and Damon, and under their cloaks,Damon and Pythias enter. they have of bacon, a gammon.

sp.speaker: Pup. P.
sp.p: Drawer, fill some wine here.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: How, some wine there? there's company already, sir, pray forbear!

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: 'Tis hero.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Yes, but she will not be taken, after sack, and fresh herring, with your dunmow-bacon.

sp.speaker: Pup. p
sp.p: You lie, it's Westfabian.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Westphalian you should say.

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: Leander and Hero are kissing. if you hold not your peace, you are a coxcomb, I would say.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: What's here? what's here? kiss, kiss, upon kiss.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Ay, wherefore should they not? what harm is in this? 'tis mistress hero.

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: Mistress hero's a whore.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Is she a whore? keep you quiet, or sir knave out of door.

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: Knave out of door?

sp.speaker: Pup. H.
sp.p: Yes, knave, out of door.

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: Whore out of door.

sp.speaker: Pup. H.
sp.p: here the puppets quarrel and fall together by the ears. I say, knave, out of door.

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: I say, whore, out of door.

sp.speaker: Pup. P.
sp.p: Yea, so say I too.

sp.speaker: Pup. H.
sp.p: Kiss the whore o'the arse.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Now you ha' something to do: you must kiss her of the arse she says:

sp.speaker: Pup. D. P.
sp.p: So we will, so we will.

sp.speaker: Pup. H.
sp.p: O my haunches, oh my haunches, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Standest thou still?
Leander, where art thou? standest thou still like a sot,
And not offer'st to break both their heads with a pot?
See who's at thine elbow, there! Puppet Jonas and Cupid.

sp.speaker: Pup. i
sp.p: Upon 'em Leander, be not so stupid. they fight.

sp.speaker: Pup. L.
sp.p: You goat-bearded slave!

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: You whoremaster knave.

sp.speaker: Pup. L.
sp.p: Thou art a whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Pup. i
sp.p: Whoremasters all.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: See, Cupid with a word has ta'en up the brawl.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: These be fine vapours!

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: By this good day they fight bravely! do they not, Numps?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Yes, they lacked but you to be their second, all this while.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: This tragical encounter, falling out thus to busy us,
It raises up the ghost of their friend Dionysius:
Not like a monarch, but the master of a school,
In a scrivener's furred gown, which shows he is no fool.
For therein he hath wit enough to keep himself warm.
O Demon he cries, and Pythias; what harm,
Hath poor Dionysius done you in his grave,
That after his death, you should fall out thus, and rave,
And call amorous Leander whoremaster knave?

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: I cannot, I will not, I promise you endure it.

div.head: Act. v. scene. V.
div.stage: To them Busy.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Down with Dagon, down with Dagon; 'tis I, will no longer endure your profanations.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: What mean you, sir?

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: I will remove Dagon there, I say, that idol, that heathenish idol, that remains (As I may say) a beam, a very beam, not a beam of the sun, nor a beam of the moon, nor a beam of a balance, neither a house-beam, nor a weaver's beam, but a beam in the eye, in the eye of the brothers; a very great beam, an exceeding great beam; such as are your stage players, rhymers, and morris-dancers, who have walked hand in hand, in contempt of the brothers, and the cause; and been born out by instruments, of no mean countenance.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Sir, I present nothing, but what is licenced by authority.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: Thou art all licence, even licentiousness itself, Shimei!

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I have the master of the revels' hand for't, sir.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: The master of rebel's hand, thou hast; Satan's! hold thy peace, thy scurrility shut up thy mouth, thy profession is damnable, and in pleading for it, thou dost plead for Baal. I have long opened my mouth wide, and gaped, I have gaped as the oyster for the tide after thy destruction ‚ñ™ but cannot compass it by suit, or dispute; so that I look for a bickering, ere long, and then a battle.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Good banbury-vapours.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Friend, you'd have an ill match on't, if you bicker with him here, though he be no man o'the fist, he has friends that will go to cuffs for him, Numps, will not you take our side?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Sir, it shall not need, in my mind; he offers him a fairer course, to end it by disputation! hast thou nothing to say for thyself, in defence of thy quality?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Faith, sir, I am not well studied in these controversies, between the hypocrites and us. But here's one of my motion, puppet Donisius shall undertake him, and I'll venture the cause on't.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Who? my hobby-horse? will he dispute with him?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Yes, sir, and make a hobby-ass of him, I hope.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: That's excellent! indeed he looks like the best scholar of 'em all. Come, sir, you must be as good as your word, now.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: I will not fear to make my spirit, and gifts known! assist me zeal, fill me, fill me, that is, make me full.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: What a desperate, profane wretch is this! is there any ignorance, or impudence like his? to call his zeal to fill him against a puppet?

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: I know no fitter match, than a puppet to commit with an hypocrite!

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: First, I say unto thee, idol, thou hast no calling.

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: You lie, I am called Dionisius.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: The motion says you lie, he is called Dionysius i'the matter, and to that calling he answers.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: I mean no vocation, idol, no present lawful calling.

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: Is yours a lawful calling?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: The motion asketh, if yours be a lawful calling?

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Yes, mine is of the spirit.

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: Then idol is a lawful calling.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: He says, than idol is a lawful calling! for you called him idol, and your calling is of the spirit.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Well disputed, hobby-horse!

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Take not part with the wicked young gallant ‚ñ™ he neigheth and hinneyeth, all is but her nying sophistry. I call him idol again. Yet, I say, his calling, his profession is profane, it is profane, idol.

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: It is not profane!

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: It is not profane, he says.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: It is profane.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: It is not profane.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: It is profane.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: It is not profane.

sp.speaker: Lan
sp.p: Well said, confute him with not, still. You cannot bear him down with your base noise, sir.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Nor he me, with his treble creeking, though he creek like the chariot wheels of Satan; I am zealous for the cause ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: As a dog for a bone.

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: And I say, it is profane, as being the page of pride, and the waiting woman of vanity.

sp.speaker: Pup. D.
sp.p: Yea? what say you to your tire-women, then?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Or feather-makers i'the friars, that are o'your faction of faith? Are not they with their perukes, and their puffs, their fans, and their huffs, as much pages of pride, and waiters upon vanity? what say you? what say you? what say you?

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: I will not answer for them.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Because you cannot, because you cannot. Is a bugle-maker a lawful calling? or the confect-makers? such you have there: or your French fashioner? you'd have all the sin within yourselves, would you not? would you not?

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: No, Dagon.

sp.speaker: Pus.
sp.p: What then, Dagonet? is a puppet worse than these?

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Yes, and my main argument against you, is, that you are an abomination: for the male, among you, putteth on the apparel of the female, and the female of the male.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: You lie, you lie, you lie abominably.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Good, by my troth, he has given him the lie thrice.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: It is your old stale argument against the players, but it will not hold against the puppets; for we have neither male nor female amongst us. And that thou mayest see, if thou wilt,the puppet takes up his garment. like a malicious purblind zeal as thou art!

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: By my faith, there he has answered you, friend; by plain demonstration.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Nay, I'll prove, against ere a rabbin of'hem all, that my standing is as lawful as his; that I speak by inspiration, as well as he; that I have as little to do with learning as he; and do scorn her helps as much as he.

sp.speaker: Bvs,
sp.p: I am confuted, the cause hath failed me.

sp.speaker: Pus.
sp.p: Then be converted, be converted.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Be converted, I pray you, and let the play go on!

sp.speaker: Bus.
sp.p: Let it go on. For I am changed, and will become a beholder with you!

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: That's brave i'faith, thou hast carried it away, hobby-horse, on with the play!

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Stay, now do I forbid, I Adam Overdoo! sit still, I charge you. the justice discovers himself.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: What, my brother in-law!

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: My wise guardian!

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Justice Overdoo!

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: It is time, to take enormity by the fore head, and brand it ‚ñ™ for, I have discovered enough.

div.head: Act. v. scene. Vi.
div.stage: To them, Qvarlous. (Like the madman) Pvre-craft. (A while after) John. to them Trovble-all. Ursla. Nightigale.

sp.speaker: Qvar.
sp.p: Nay, come mistress Bride. You must do as I do, now. You must be mad with me, in truth. I have here justice Overdoo for it.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Peace good Trouble-all; come hither, and you shall trouble none. to the cutpurse, and mistress Litwit.I will take the charge of you, and your friend too, you also, young man shall be my care, stand there.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Now, mercy upon me.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Would we were away, whit, these are dangerous vapours,the rest are stealing away. best fall off with our birds, for fear o'the cage.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Stay, is not my name your terror?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Yesh faith man, and it ish for tat, we would be gone man.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: O gentlemen! did you not see a wife of mine? I ha' lost my little wife, as I shall be trusted: my little pretty Win, I left her at the great woman's house in trust yonder, the pig-woman's, with captain Jordan, and captain whit, very good men, and I cannot hear of her. Poor fool, I fear she's stepped aside. Mother, did you not see win?

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: If this grave matron be your mother, sir, stand by her, et digito compesce labellum, I may perhaps spring a wife for you, anon. Brother Bartholmew, I am sadly sorry, to see you so lightly given, and such a disciple of enormity: with your grave governor Humphrey: but stand you both there, in the middle place; I will reprehend you in your course. Mistress grace, let me rescue you out of the hands of the stranger.

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: Pardon me, sir, I am a kinsman of hers.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Are you so? of what name, sir?

sp.speaker: Win-w.
sp.p: Win-wife, sir ‚ñ™

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p:
Master Win-wife? I hope you have won no wife of her, sir. If you have, I will examine the possibility of it, at fit leisure. Now, to my enormities: look upon me, oh London! and see me, oh Smithfield; the example of justice, and mirror of magistrates: the true top of formality, and scourge of enormity. Harken unto my
labours, and but observe my discoveries; and compare Hercules with me, if thou dar'st, of old; or Columbus; Magellan; or our country man drake of later times: stand forth you weeds of enormity, and spread. First, rabbi busy, thou superlunatical hypocrite, next,to Busy, to lantern, to the horse courser, and cutpurse. Then Cap. whit, and mistress Littlewit. thou other extremity, thou profane professor of puppetry, little better than poetry: than thou strong debaucher, and seducer of youth; witness this easy and honest young man: now thou esquire of dames, madams, and twelvepenny ladies: now my green madam herself, of the price. Let me unmask your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: O my wife, my wife, my wife!

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Is she your wife? Red te Harpocratem!

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: By your leave, stand by my masters, be uncovered.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: O stay him, stay him, help to cry, nightingale; my pan,enter Trouble-all. my pan.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: He has stolen gammer Ursla's pan.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Yes, and I fear no man but justice Overdoo.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Ursla? where is she? O the sow of enormity, this!to Ursla, and nightingale. welcome, stand you there, you songster, there.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: An' please your worship, I am in no fault: a gentleman stripped him in my booth, and borrowed his gown, and his hat; and he ran away with my goods, here, for it.

sp.speaker: Jus¬∑
sp.p: Then this is the true madman, and you are the enormity!

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: You are i'the right, I am mad,to Quarlous. but from the gown outward.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Stand you there.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Where you please, sir.

sp.speaker: Over
sp.p: O lend me a basin, I am sick, I am sick;mistress Overdoo is sick: and her husband is silenced. where's Mr. Overdoo? Bridget, call hither my Adam.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Die very own wise, i'fait, worshipful Adam.

sp.speaker: Over.
sp.p: Will not my Adam come at me? shall I see him no more then?

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p:
Sir, why do you not go on with the enormity? are you oppressed with it? I'll help you: hark you sir, i'your ear, your innocent young man, you have ta'en such care of, all this day, is a cutpurse; that hath got all your brother Cokes his things, and helped you to your beating, and the stocks; if you have a mind to hang him now, and show him your magistrates wit, you may ‚ñ™ but I should think it were better, recovering the goods, and to save your estimation in him. I thank you sir for the gift of your ward, mrs. Grace: look you, here is your hand and seal, by the way mr. Win-wife give you joy, you are Palemon, you are possessed o'the gentlewoman, but she must pay me value, here's warrant for it. And honest madman, there's thy gown, and cap again; I thank thee for my wife. Nay, I can be mad, sweet heart, when I please, still; never fear me:to the widow.
and careful Numps, where's he? I thank him for my licence.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: Wasp misseth the licence. how!

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Numps.

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: I'll be hanged then.

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: Look i'your box, Numps, nay, sir, stand not you fixed here, like a stake in Finsbury to be shot at, or the whipping post i'the fair, but get your wife out o'the air, it will make her worse else; and remember you are but Adam, flesh, and blood! you have your frailty, forget your other name of Overdoo, and invite us all to supper. There you and I will compare our discoveries; and drown the memory of all enormity in your biggest bowl at home.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: How now, Numps, ha' you lost it? I warrant, 'twas when thou wert i'the stocks: why dost not speak?

sp.speaker: Was.
sp.p: I will never speak while I live, again, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: Nay, Humphrey, if I be patient, you must be so too; this pleasant conceited gentleman hath wrought upon my judgement, and prevailed: I pray you take care of your sick friend, mistress Alice, and my good friends all ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Qva.
sp.p: And no enormities.

sp.speaker: Ivs.
sp.p: I invite you home, with me to my house, to supper: I will have none fear to go along, for my intents are ad correctionem, non ad destructionem; ad aedificandum, non ad diruendum: so lead on.

sp.speaker: Cok.
sp.p: Yes, and bring the actors along, we'll ha'the rest o'the play at home.

div.head: The epilogue.
div.l: Your majesty hath seen the play, and you
Can best allow it from your care, and view.
You know the scope of writers, and what store,
Of leave is given them, if they take not more,
And turn it into licence: you can tell
If we have used that leave you gave us, well ‚ñ™
Or whether we to rage, or licence break,
Or be profane, or make profane men speak?
This is your power to judge (Great sir) and not
The envy of a few. Which if we have got,
We value less what their dislike can bring,
If it so happy be, t'have pleased the King.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
